139492384.review:
"Trick or treat, be ready for defeat!"

[i]Costume Quest[/i] is a party-based role-playing video game developed and published by Double Fine Productions.

[b]Story[/b]
Taking place on Halloween you play as either Reynold or Wren, new twins in the neighbourhood who want to make friends and get candy during said spooky event. After picking one of them to be "in charge" (be a playable character), other sibling gets kidnapped by a monster, forcing you to save them and get home before curfew!

[b]Gameplay[/b]
Costume Quest is a small sized RPG where you and your party explore, complete quests and participate in turn based combat! Goal is to save your sibling by completing main quests across different locations to further progress in the story.

Because it's a Halloween themed title, it features elements fitting into said celebration. Throughout the game you collect loads of candy from combat, exploration or trick-and-treating, with these sweet treats exchanged for battle stamps that grant you new abilities or improve certain aspects of your characters.

Main aspect of the game lies within costumes. Used by your party members, they feature special powers helpful during exploration and offer different abilities for combat. While some are story related, you can collect more of them by exploring areas to gather costume parts, and with proper schematics you will unlock new shiny outfits in no time.

During exploration you can complete side quests or engage in combat against monsters.
Here costumes your characters are wearing become giant versions of themselfs, coming with different statistics.
Combat is turn based, your party performs actions you choose, then your opponents.
It's pretty simple, you can select and attack certain enemy, block to receive less damage, or use a special move if you can as it requires few turns to load.
Actions are connected to quick time events where hitting a button or combination at a right time deals biggest damage possible or lets you receive less from enemies.
At the end of the fight (if you won) you collect experience points and candy.
Leveling up system is very basic as collecting enough xp to earn a level up simply upgrades your health and damage you deal.

[b]Playtime and replayability[/b]
Completing everything game had to offer in one playthrough took me 5 hours!
This is more of a "one and done" snack, unless you want to complete some side quests or achievements you missed, no real reason to replay it in my book.

[b]Pros and cons[/b]
Enjoyable turn based combat is easy to figure out and with costumes having a role in how it plays out, there is a nice layer of strategy surrounded in picking them and battle stamps to find your winning method. Simple RPG mechanics including progression system, okay variety of side quests and basic storyline will keep your interest for those few hours you spend with a title. Plus whole Halloween theme with good visual style has certain charm surrounding it. 

On a bit more "eh" side, game could use a bit more polish. Controls in certain moments during exploration are clunky, and combat animations get quickly repetitive as each costume has only one of these per attack.
Additionally game takes a moment to fill up your party so if you, like me, go for side stuff before moving into main bits, you might have a frustrating time dealing with number disadvantage during combat. Fortunately once your party is full, odds become equal! 

Ultimately it's a good and short yet nothing spectacular title. It does what it should and nothing more.

[b]Final words and conclusion[/b]
PC version automatically comes with "Grubbins on Ice" DLC which continues the story of our little heroes after events from main game, so be sure to check it out!

Costume Quest doesn't excel in any area but its turn based combat, exploration and story provide decent entertainement for evening or two.

Feel free to check out [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/31947302/] my curator page [/url] for more reviews!

124961427.review:
[h1]Costume Quest Review[/h1]

[i]**Spoiler Free**[/i]

[u]Quick Review:[/u] Costume Quest is a cute and simple turn-based RPG that celebrates the spirit of Halloween and captures the childhood joy of trick-or-treating. What it lacks in depth or strategy, it makes up for with charm and atmosphere. I recommend playing this around Halloween, or if you’re new to the genre or gaming in general.


[u]Gameplay:[/u] A review here on Steam described Costume Quest as “baby’s first RPG,” and I think that’s an apt summary.  The gameplay is basic and straight forward. You explore little neighborhoods searching for candy by trick-or-treating at houses or smashing objects around the environment. Every house must be visited to progress the story. It’s a linear story, so  there are no branching storylines, and no decisions to make in conversations.

The candy can be used to purchase Battle Stamps, which are equipped to your characters to add an ability or effect in battle. One stamp can be assigned per party member.

Of course, Costume Quest is all about the costumes. Costumes must be crafted by finding the materials needed around the world. Most costumes will give you an ability you can use while exploring the world, allowing you to reach new destinations that would otherwise be blocked. Each costume will also give you  a different ability in battle. I thought the costumes were handled well given how simple the game is.

Speaking of battles, the turn-based system is very simple. On your turn, you can either attack with your basic attack, use your special if you’ve charged your meter, or flee the encopunter. You charge your meter every three turns. If you have a battle stamp ability, you can use that too. The limited combat options give you very little room to experiment or strategize. It’s just very straightforward. I actually lost a couple of battles, so there’s “some" skill involved, but it’s minimal. (Basically, you just need to make sure you're succeeding on the quicktime events.) And if you lose, you spawn right before the battle, so it’s no big deal.

The one thing about combat that makes it feel more engaging is the quicktime events. Every attack (and defense) you make requires a quicktime event to maximize its effectiveness. These are not combo heavy events. You either have to time a button press at a certain point, or react fast enough to press a button in a limited time window. While I felt this feature dramatically helped the gameplay feel more interesting, I actually think this could be frustrating for a new or younger gamer because the windows are pretty small. And if you’re not familiar with gaming button layouts, there isn’t enough time to look down and check what button you need to click. Obviously for any experienced gamer this isn’t an issue.

Character stats are minimal: Health and Attack Power. That’s it. No dodging, defense, critical chance, etc. It’s very simple. Characters heal to full health after each encounter.

There is also a mini game about bobbing for apples. You simply eat enough ripe apples before the timer ends. If you complete all three tiers you’ll get a card to add to your collection. Cards are collected throughout the game. I don’t believe they impact the game at all. They’re just collectibles.

The game takes around 5 hours to complete. Outside of going back to gather collectibles you missed, there's not really any reply value. There is also an included DLC called Grubbins on Ice, which is probably 2+ hours of extra game and story.

Overall the gameplay is basic and simple. It’s at a level a new or younger gamer would find appropriate (assuming they know their way around a controller for the quick time events).


[u]User Interface:[/u] The UI is artistically consistent with the rest of the game with its hand-drawn aesthetic. The text uses a hand-drawn font, and action prompts are colorful and squiggly. The inventory menu is presented as a notebook, so the whole game looks like it was designed by a kid (in a good way).

The speech bubbles auto-continue conversations. I found the speed of the text to be fine, but it would have been nice to have an option to slow them down in case you wanted to read a little slower.

The key bindings are also remappable, which is good.

[u]Atmosphere:[/u] Let’s face it, this is probably why you want to play the game, and it’s why I recommend it. When have you ever seen a game literally about trick-or-treating? It’s a cute, wholesome experience of Halloween that celebrates this fun holiday of childhood. The whole game is presented from a kid’s point of view. From the hand-drawn artstyle, to the conversations, to the battles.

The premise is: Your sibling is stolen by a candy-stealing goblin, and in order to advance your rescue mission quest, you need to collect candy by trick-or-treating to unlock the goblin gates and fight an evil witch...because if you come home without your sibling, you’ll be grounded by your parents. This totally sounds like a story some little kids would come up with! All of these monster encounters take place right in the middle of civilization, and none of the adults believe you when you tell them these monsters are out and about. The casual dismissal of the adults is the kind of humor and thematic consistency that plays throughout the game.

The battles are also pretty cute. Depending on your costume, when you enter battle you will transform into an epic version of that costume. When you’re a kid and you dress up for Halloween, part of the fun is make-believing that you really are this awesome robot, or you really are a powerful knight. The translation of this young mindset to a video game works really well here, and reminds me of the fun times I had growing up with Halloween!

The music is very Cartoony. I believe there is a term in music composition called “Mickey Mousing” -- when you write music very on-the-nose to line up with hits and beats in the cartoon. The soundtrack has that kind of vibe. There is a foreboding jolting character with a light-hearted instrumentation. And the battle music has kind of a huffing-and-puffing fast pace to it. I guess it all sounds like a B-Horror film. It’s nothing memorable, and on its own I would find it annoying. But it works well with the game.

[u]Conclusion:[/u] Costume Quest is able to pull off a worthwhile experience despite its simple gameplay because of its strong atmospheric foundation. It’s commitment to presenting Halloween from that of a kid whose having fun going on an epic quest to get candy succeeds throughout its design. This is not a complicated game to play. A younger player may find this appropriate, and older gamers could find this boring. But I think if you go into it knowing what to expect, you’ll enjoy your time being a kid again, trick-or-treating on Halloween. Recommend.

Art: For a game that was published in 2010, the art has aged really well. I mean it. Lots of games made more recently have aged so much worse, and I'm pretty sure it's because of this game's art style. So, the art's good.
Writing: Great! Mostly comedy, with some nice family moments (no spoilers, ya gotta play it for yourself).
Audio/Music: Music is a bit on the sparse side, but the ambient sounds of a night of trick-or-treating does add to the atmosphere. Audio balance and audio effects are good enough.
Gameplay: Simplistic, not exactly challenging, but still rewarding when you figure things out on your own. Yes the game drops hints to its puzzles and puzzle fights, but it's still not truly holding your hand. The game itself is a bit short, but honestly it's a bit of a relief to play a short RPG since most RPGs tend to run long.
Ending: I've decided to start adding this as a ranking parameter because I'm really tired of games with lousy endings. Bad endings make a game worse, even though they have nothing to do with much of any of a game except the writing and maybe the art. And honestly, I've played way too many games with really terribly done endings. That said, this game has a good ending in my opinion. Well done.

In conclusion: I do recommend playing this game. Yes it was made for kids in 2010, but it's good clean fun that can enjoyed by anyone of any age.

Side note: played this today to fulfill a promise. When I got this game, I told myself I'd reserve it for when I was having a terrible Halloween week and needed that week improved. And, well, here I am now. My Halloweek has been improved! Thanks Game and Devs!

113487899.review: Presentation can go a long way towards an enjoyable experience in gaming. I love to be engaged mechanically with this hobby, but that doesn't detract from the possibility of finding compelling experiences that are more atmosphere than action. Take Costume Quest, for example. It's hardly got any depth for an rpg. It's very brief - comprised of three short main areas. There's nothing epic or serious in tone about it. It comes off as more of a "baby's first rpg" in terms of overall weight, but it has such a wonderful sense of charm. What could - to most Americans anyway - be more relatable than being a kid going in search of candy on Halloween? (although that convention seems to be waning along with many others, for better or worse) And that backdrop, with the sense of mystery and foreboding intrinsic to the holiday, along with the excitement of becoming another character for the evening, is the perfect setting for an imaginative adventure that has the potential to reconnect you with the spirit of your own youth. Giving the various collectible costumes powers and personalities of their own is an excellent idea that I found to be really playful and intuitive. The combat itself, while dreadfully simple and offering very little challenge, was nonetheless enjoyable because I was so absorbed by this light-hearted tale of being a kid on adventure on my most favorite of holidays. While Costume Quest may lack substance, much like the vacuous treats associated with the holiday, it was similarly sweet and delicious while it lasted. 4/5

I got Costume Quest as part of a Double Fine bundle and didn't know anything about it beforehand. Turns out it's a fun little RPG, reminding me of Paper Mario, in Halloween style. On a quest to save your sibling from candy-hoarding monsters, you collect a few like-minded party members and a series of costumes, battle badges and of course, candy. Whenever you enter a combat encounter, the costumes dramatically transform your party into more convincing versions of the robots, knights, ninjas and vampires they represent. Each costume has a regular attack and a special attack that might do extra damage, heal party members or provide protection. Battle badges can be swapped in and out to provide extra advantages. You explore, collect and fight your way through several areas of your town in search of your sibling.

The gameplay is uncomplicated, and not too challenging - there's no game overs, if your group loses a battle, you can simply try again. This should make it very suited for all ages. The writing is both cute and clever. I think the game could've benefitted from voice acting to round it out, but I think this was a relatively small budget project. A fun, relatively casual game.

107595374.review:
In the spirit of Halloween, I decided to finally make my way through Costume Quest and its sequel (review to follow). Originally released in 2010 on 7th generation consoles, it made its way to PC about a year later, with the Grubbins on Ice DLC included.

The game itself was born out of an “Amnesia Fortnight”; a session within Double Fine Productions that focused on quickly creating prototypes and potential game ideas. I recently spent a week at my job doing something similar, which was a ton of fun. It’s an opportunity to forget about the unchanging day-to-day work, and focus on simply being creative without restrictions. The final product here is extremely reminiscent of such a brainstorming session: imaginative and filled with energy, but also occasionally missing some details that aren’t entirely thought out.

Despite it’s immediate charm, I was a little unimpressed with the technical fidelity of Costume Quest. No, a game like this isn’t meant to be a graphical showcase, but there could have been some nicer details and textures throughout. The art style itself is great; the characters themselves look good, and most objects in the environment are well modelled. Being a game that takes place on Halloween, the locales of a suburb and mall make sense, but many sections in each hub area simply feel barren, especially with a lack of strong ambient music. Even the additional area in the DLC offers a very flat and colourless atmosphere, which isn’t fun to play through. And while this is a slow, turn-based game that doesn’t require an ultra-high framerate, the 30 FPS cap is annoying.

It can be easy to overlook these visual faults however, because the game endlessly oozes charm. Every other NPC you talk to will share some cheeky dialogue or pop culture reference which made me chuckle. Even some of the victory animations after combat encounters are hilarious. Honestly, I’d say this game masterfully delivers consistent comedy. It’s like bam, funny quip, bam, funny costume, etc, but not in an overbearing way. Rather, a way that leaves a smile on the players face and keeps them feeling cozy throughout. Despite the simple and childish appearance, I was invested in Wren and Reynold’s story, and was always eager to find out where their ridiculous adventure was headed next.

Besides running around and completing a random assortment of quests, the main gameplay loop involves engaging enemies in turn-based combat. It’s a pretty mindless and easy system, which suits this game in my opinion. I’m not the biggest fan of turn-based combat to begin with, and unless it’s something like Pokémon where there are all these unique types and memorable monsters, I don’t want a slow combat system to get in the way of story and exploration. Admittedly, the combat could have been improved with a little more complexity, just to offer some more interactivity for the player. After about an hour or two into the game, I immediately went into autopilot mode at the start of every combat encounter. I also thought equipping different costumes was a bit of a chore. I wanted to use all of them in combat, but speeding around in the robot costume was easiest; as is forgetting to change it before encountering an enemy.

I give Costume Quest a 7.0/10. Despite a few flaws, it’s a good game and a cute, unique experience. I definitely recommend picking up during any Steam sale where it regularly gets discounted for a couple bucks, and I highly recommend adding this anyone’s yearly Halloween media consumption.

Halloween isn't a festivity celebrated in my country and I have no special feelings towards it, no memories to longingly think about, no nostalgia-driven wonder. And yet I loved this game and felt like I was revisiting parts of my childhood. This is the true power of Costume Quest: it makes you feel like a kid again and brings with it that joy of donning a super-hero suit and becoming one in that magical way that only a kid's imagination can deliver and that we can all relate too, even if you did not do it on October 31. It is a colorful adventure with RPG elements that manages to transmit the love and wonder for Halloween put into it by the folks at Double Fine.

You play a brother or a sister who embarks on a quest to save his/her sibling kidnapped by candy-stealing monsters on that most magic of nights, the All Hallow's Eve. You will recruit other kids to aid you on your noble quest: knocking on doors all through suburbia, trick or treating your way into the monsters' magic homeland with the aid of some awesome costumes that you have to build out of everyday objects found throughout the map. During battle scenes, you will transform into whatever your cardbox/tinfoil/rags costume depicts and have basic moves as well as special ones for each costume to defeat your opponents (some are standard support characters, healing and buffing party members, other rely on attacking either through leeching life out of enemies or delivering high-powered blows).
On the negative side, I would say that its main flaw is that combat can get a bit repetitive after awhile and you have to force yourself to switch costumes regularly in order to find diversity instead of sticking with the awesome combination that the initial costumes can provide and mostly carry you throughout the game... there isn't much depth in the progression and leveling up of the characters but then again this game isn't meant to be a "true" RPG. 
Even with the Winter/Christmas DLC, reaching 100% completion (finding every secret and costume) didn't take me more than 8hrs, but, at the low price it goes for, that aspect is hardly a fault.

This is a perfect game for anyone with fond memories of Halloween, as it perfectly captures the fun and nostalgia of trick-or-treating, seasonal festivals, and imaginary adventures in a homemade costume. I recently lived in a country where Halloween is not widely observed, and when locals asked about it’s appeal, everything I would name can be found in Costume Quest. 

Regarding gameplay, this is a very simple turn-based RPG in which you and the neighborhood kids adventure through town to rescue your twin sibling from candy-swiping monsters. This is a fantastic introduction to the genre if the player is young or just inexperienced with RPGs (like I was during my first playthrough). Your party member’s stats are clearly spelled out as a combination of their costume and one stamp, and battles tend to favor the player through little things like always letting you go first, allowing you to make attacks of opportunity but not the enemy, and generous save and checkpoints. Outside of battle, you’ll explore 3 areas (plus 1 with the “Grubbins on Ice” postgame) with side-quest staples like fetch quests, item trading, and exploration using costume abilities. 

The only knock I can really give this game is that if you have anything beyond beginner experience with RPGs, then you may find Costume Quest far too easy. It isn’t hard to pick out the best party build, which means many of your costumes will be used once for an achievement before you switch back to a team that steamrolls through encounters. On the other hand, it’s hard to fault something made with children in mind for being too simple: the real appeal for adults will be the nostalgia, art direction, and the Double Fine brand of goofy humor. 

I’d place Costume Quest as a kind of light-hearted and charming Halloween work that can be enjoyed every year when the season rolls around, just like watching “It’s the Great Pumpkin, Charlie Brown” or “The Nightmare Before Christmas”. It’s definitely a game I will play again when the jack o’ lanterns come out!

97113623.review:
Costume Quest is an unfortunate case, a game brimming with charm brought down by its core gameplay loop. For all its wit and whimsy, as an RPG, it’s just not all that fun.
	Predictably, Costume Quest’s gameplay is broken up into its overworld exploration and its combat. Moving through the overworld is agreeable enough for the most part. You’ll talk to the endearing denizens and take on basic side-quests. But it becomes clear repetition is quite prevalent. Three main locales comprise the main adventure, and you’ll go through the same tasks – find trading cards for characters, bob for apples, knock on doors for candy, and repeat. Some areas require use of your costumes’ particular skills, such as using the knight costume’s shield to protect yourself from falling debris. It’s all basic stuff, but inoffensive and acceptable had Costume Quest managed to engage more in its combat.
	But therein lies the real problem. Costume Quest’s combat is dreary within a few bouts and brain-dead soon after. You can get away with wailing on foes with high attack costumes from the very first fight all the way through to the credits. Once I cemented my strategy – and to call it a strategy is generous – it carried me all the way, save for exchanging one piece of equipment for the final boss because of its immunity to a status effect. The combat never evolves or challenges, and it makes for a tedious quest. Costume Quest’s fatal flaw is not its repetitive gameplay loop, even with its brevity – rather, it’s a failure to find a compelling hook for said loop.
	At least the presentation fares better. While it’s disappointing there’s only one battle theme, the soundtrack is whimsical and pleasant, with a strong balance of silliness and wonder to capture the spirit of a child’s Halloween quest. The art style and character design is unmistakably Double Fine, and that’s just dandy. The colorful environments, chunky models, and cel-shading make Costume Quest stand out, though you may want to bring the brightness up a few notches in the options menu. When you stop at a house for trick-or-treating, that house’s lights go out, making  it easier to keep track of where you’ve been, which is all the better since I still got a tad turned around, as the environments can blend together.
	The writing stands out for its wit, with humor akin to a Peanuts skit. I always looked forward to a new area primarily for what the locals would have to say. The world and characters are immediately appealing, though I wish the protagonists were allowed more development.
	The Grubbins on Ice expansion is pretty much more of the same, with a large but linear setting which still falls prey to a repetitive loop. Pretty much any of my critiques and praises for the main quest could be echoed here.
	Costume Quest could be so much more, but it’s simply not fun to play. Double Fine has a cozy world here accompanied by clever writing, but this isn’t a quest worth taking.

91537211.review:
Basically it's Halloween condensed into a single game. With trick-or-treating, costumes, apple bobbing, sweets and monsters. It's so good that, close to Oct 31st 2020, I posted this game on social media and suggested parents buy this for their kids as a substitute as trick-or-treating was banned due to the pandemic.
 
The plot (no spoilers here) is that it's Halloween you are a child going out trick-or-treating. Until you notice all the sweets are being stolen by real monsters. Your sibling, who is dressed as a candy corn, is mistaken for a real one and "stolen" as well. You then embark on a quest to track them to their lair, save your sibling and the sweets.

The gameplay is split wandering through various environments and combating monsters.
In one there are main quests, side quests, mini games, some puzzle solving and new costumes to collect. You also need to collect sweets from houses and there's a chance you'll either be confronted by a candy-giving adult or a monster you need to combat, it's trick-or-treating with a bit of role reversal.
In combat, you transform into a real version of the costume you are wearing and engage in turn based combat with your enemy. 
At first I didn't think I would like combat that was slow paced and required no more effort then choosing an action and pressing a key once. But the game made it more interesting, on top of selecting your attack you need to press a key at the right time to make it more effective, the key is randomly selected each time and different attacks have different uses of keys. Also, you can block enemy attacks which also involve timing and random keys. All this means that even though it's turn based it keeps you on your toes. I also loved seeing the fighter versions of these costumes, your in for a surprise when you deploy the fries mascot costume.

There are also "Creepy Treats" cards to collect. Supposedly they are like baseball cards for various fictional sweets. They don't do anything and some might complain they are just there to lure completionists. But I liked the crazy sweet ideas they came up with. But also, if you collect them all you unlock an overpowered costume.

However, as the game progresses you can find yourself really overpowered and unless you are fighting a boss, which happens rarely, it's no challenge for you. In fact, with the right costumes and upgrades, most of the fighting is little challenge at all. But then again it is for kids.

Also, the plot is really straight forward. It turns out there there is no master plan, just monsters stealing sweets. Also it turns out they're working for someone else but we're never given why and he never gets any back story. 

So if you are a kid or have kids there's challenge and fun to be had here. If your're not a kid, it's little challenge but still fun. And either way it's good for experiencing a little taste of Halloween when ever you want.

In the Market for a fun little RPG with no major time commitment?
If so, this could be the game for you, particularly if you're reading this review around Halloween.

A creative take on the Turn based JRPG gameplay, a pretty unique visual style & some decent humor mixed in to boot. The costumes themselves are pretty well designed, and hunting down all of the components needed to piece together some of the stranger outfits is rewarding when you see them come to life in combat.

Beyond selecting which moves to dish out, there's a simple quick-time element where attacks and blocks are boosted by tapping the corresponding key with precise timing. While it's not a very complex system, there's just enough depth to keep enemy encounters interesting. 
Some costumes are offensive powerhouses, while others play supportive roles in combat similar to a Job system seen in some Final Fantasy titles. Each suit's special ability charges with every round, letting you unleash special attacks ranging from a missile barrage to the most Star-spangled Healing move i've ever seen in a game (when you see it you'll know). As great as the costumes are on their own, picking up collectible battle stamps also lets you boost each character's power with different buffs, again putting an appropriate spin on the concept to suit the tone & setting. 

This version includes the Grubbins on Ice DLC which is a welcome piece of additional content. The expansion picks up after the original game ends and continues the story into the monsters' homeland of Repugia.

Verdict; 
You’d be hard-pressed to find a better Halloween-themed Turn based RPG.

I also figured I might as well talk about how much I like Costume Quest! It's a short, simple, fun little Halloween adventure perfect for a break between all the spooky games I torture myself with every October. It's super cute. The characters are super likable. The concept of hiding random encounters in houses to trick-or-treat is really funny to me. And the ridiculous kaiju-sized turn based battles have some spectacularly silly animations and attacks.

There's not a lot of depth to the battle system; instead of keeping you engaged with varied abilities and tactics, Costume Quest relies more on simple back and forth Paper Mario style action-commands and one slowly charging special move. I can see why someone would find it a bit too slight, but I thought the battles moved at a good clip and the mixing and matching costumes and battle stamps gave me enough of a basic tactical bent for my JRPG addled brain.

It probably goes without saying but the writing is really good. Double Fine games almost always have really good writing so I've come to expect it, but it's not like really good writing just magically appears in the game so kudos on the writing team once again. It's unfortunate though that the game's dialogue text auto-advances; it'd be fine if the adventure was voiced, but it's (understandably) not. It didn't overly impact me, but that's definitely an accessibility concern for slower readers.

Still, Costume Quest is definitely a cheap and wonderful little treat, perfect for October. Now to speed through the sequel before I run out of spooky month.

It’s that time of year again, Halloween and Trick-or-Treating for everyone. That is until you run into some alie- er, I mean, Repugians, who are hell bent on taking all the candy in your neighborhood, including your sibling who’s dressed as a candy corn. It’s time to team up with some new friends to save your sibling and Halloween in Costume Quest.

[h1]The Good[/h1][i]Nice Halloween story, with an added cool use for costumes.[/i]

As noted in the intro, the story is centered around Halloween, with two siblings getting ready to go Trick-or-Treating, until you run into some weird creatures that kindaps one of the siblings and steals candies from the neighborhood. In general, it’s a simple story to understand, has plenty of humor on the way and puts a nice reminder on what a fun night of Halloween should be. Having kids enjoying Trick or Treating in costumes with their friends and parents/guardians.

A bonus plus that should be noted is the use of costumes in this game. Not only is there a nice variety, but each can help you explore your surroundings, be used to help you in battles against the enemy, and they each have their different strengths and special moves that provides a nice flash for those looking for an added flare.

[h1]The Bad[/h1][i]Battles can be potentially unfavored in the beginning.[/i]

The battle system is fairly simple to get used to and the enemies that you fight provide a good challenge… as you progress through the game, that is.

Early on, the enemies fight at almost the same strength as your team. While this does indeed give a good challenge, a false move or bad team combination can cost you a battle very easily. This makes the beginning of the game feel more difficult than necessary. Once you get past the first section, the difficulty starts to lighten up and the rest of the game becomes easier to manage.

[h1]The Ugly[/h1][i]Certain areas aren’t oriented properly.[/i]

Costume Quest doesn’t have any camera movement. As a result, the camera is fixed in an isometric position. For the most part, the camera angle is setup well, with the only exceptions being in situations where you go to the back areas, such as behind a house or in a wooded area. In those areas, there’s a lot of obstruction and the trees aren’t transparent enough for you to get a good view of such areas, thus making it difficult to find hidden goodies.


While the beginning of the game might be tough to get around, Costume Quest does deliver the rest of the way through it’s story and gameplay. With “you-know-what” going on around the world, why not enjoy a little Halloween adventure from your living room? Pick this game up and enjoy the ride.

Costume Quest in a neat adventure RPG set on a Halloween setting, in which you and your friends go trick or treating while also battling monsters in costumes. It’s a cute idea that has a unique charm with the art style, animations and music.
Being an RPG, there are main and side quests to do, “random” battles (the enemies have fixed locations), a leveling system and lots of stuff to collect, giving you more costumes and abilities. It’s designed in a way that it’s not grindy at all, and by just going for 100% completion, which is not hard at all, you’ll reach max level and have enough candies, the game currency, to buy all abilities. It’s really a treat (pun intended) going for 100% completion, the game almost feels designed to be played that way, although you can just do the main story and be fine, since combat is easy. It’s basically a turn-based system with some timing-based attacks and limited special abilities. But this simplicity works well enough.
It’s also short, around 8-10 hours even with the included DLC, that acts as an epilogue extra chapter for the main game, and starts by default with the base game max progression, allowing you to further level up and collect even more stuff. I would prefer if the DLC was integrated in the main game using the same save file, instead of being separate without a save import option of some sort. But that’s a nitpick.
If you like short adventures with charm and a joy to 100% complete, then you can’t go wrong with this gem from Double Fine. Some easy achievements to get as well.

[i]Costume Quest[/i] is the first traditional RPG coming from the mind of Tim  Schafer at Double Fine Productions.  In [i]Costume Quest[/i], the player takes on the role of one of two fraternal twins.  The other gets kidnapped, and it is up to the player, along with two new trick-or-treating friends to rescue the other twin.  

The gameplay of [i]Costume Quest[/i] is the traditional cut-and-paste RPG.  The player controls the playable child in various areas, with more areas available with equipment upgrades.  Battles are the traditional turn-based system.  As opposed to "classes," the player selects costumes for the three party members.  Each costume acts as a class.  The game is very relaxed and is quite suitable for novice gamers.

Those who want a gentle, cute video game experience will find a lot to enjoy with [i]Costume Quest[/i].  It is relatible, simple to play, and has several moments of quirky humor.  

Using the cut-and-paste RPG system is an acceptable form of game development, but the developers need to bring something unique - a soul - to that system.  Coming from the mind of Tim Schafer, much is to be expected about the spirit and humor of the game.  Simply put, [i]Costume Quest[/i] doesn't have the Tim Schafer spirit.  Players looking for the humor of [i]Monkey Island[/i] or the spirit of [i]Psychonauts[/i] will be disappointed.  Through and through, [i]Costume Quest[/i] is a very generic RPG.  Those looking for a Tim Schafer experience may be better served with [i]Broken Age[/i] (or one of the many remastered Lucas Arts games).

[i]Costume Quest[/i] is recommended to those looking for a casual experience with a lighthearted tone throughout.  Otherwise, it may be best to look elsewhere for an RPG.

Game #68 										3.2.2020.

[h1] Boys and girls of every age, wouldn't you like to see something strange? [/h1]

You know, what’s awesome? Halloween! You know what sucks? It sucks that I live in a country where “Halloween” isn’t really celebrated (I mean we have this thing where kids go around and sing songs for candy but it’s not NEARLY as fun as Halloween). 

So what exactly is Halloween? Well, if you ask my dad, he will say how it’s a stupid American celebration where they celebrate how they burned witches. While that technically may be true, one only needs to play this game to get the true spirit of Halloween. 

The whole point of this holiday is to put on a costume and (if you are a child) go from door to door and beg for candy, and IT’S AWESOME. Even though I’ve never experienced Halloween myself, I absolutely adore this holiday. I look forward to seeing all the cool costumes people wear, how they decorate their houses, all the scary movies they show, it’s overall just a really great day.

[h1] Cute, colorful, short and made by Tim Schafer [/h1]

Costume Quest isn’t a great game only because it’s based on Halloween. It’s a great game because it’s fun, innocent, creative, colorful and, most importantly, short enough that you can beat it in about one sitting (okay, maybe 2-3 tops). 

Actually, I was going to cheat my way through this review and base it mainly on everything I remembered about this game, but as I started writing I realized that I had forgotten a lot about it (Last time I played it was back in 2015). I did, however, vividly remember that I had an absolute blast playing through it and even getting all Steam Achievements.  Well, I am happy to say that it took me very little time to remember why I loved this game so much back in 2015.

Did I mention this was made and published by Double Fine productions? Did I mention I also love their games except for a few lousy ones *cough* Brutal Legend *cough* https://store.steampowered.com/app/225260/Brutal_Legend/.

[h1] Trick or treat your way to victory [/h1]

Anyway, Costume Quest is an isometric turn based RPG where you play as a kid that goes around trick or treating. After you select between a brother and a sister, you set out in your cute little costume to go trick or treating. Little do you realize that monsters have invaded your town and they are after the most precious resource of them all: CANDY. Not just that but because your sibling dressed like a giant piece of candy corn, they kidnap him/her as well, so now, not only do you have to go around trick or treating, you have to save your sibling and defeat the monsters. Yeah, it’s safe to say that this is absolutely adorable, for me at least. What can I say? I’m just a sucker for such childish plots.

Tthe game consists of a couple of levels. Each level has a set number of quests you have to do. While I don’t wanna waste time talking about how cute all the quests are, the one quest you will have on each level is: Trick or Treating. You will go up to the front door of a house, knock on the door and yell: “Trick or Treat”. Either an adult will open and give you candy OR a monster will open a door and attack you.

[h1] A stylish turn based battle system that's so simple even a child could play it [/h1]

So now we come to our turn based RPG battles and as much as I want to praise this system, it’s extremely basic. Basic enough that even little kids can get it, which is actually a good thing. Your party consist of 3 characters (You and two more kids that trick or treat with you) and you normally fight up to 3 monsters. So, what can kids do against monsters? Why, use the powers of their costumes of course! Are you dressed like a robot? BAM! You turn into Optimus Prime! Wearing a knight’s armor! BAM! You are a knight the size of a building! Each costume has its own attacks and special abilities and the best part is you can swap them and create new ones as you progress through the game. Each costume also has a special ability that you can use while trick or treating. The battles themselves are just selecting a target and pressing the attack button where you can also do a quick-time-event to attack harder and reduce damage. Yeah, as fun as I might make this sound great, it’s extremely basic, which again, is probably a good thing. 

[h1] You might want to use a controller... [/h1]

The game features cartoony graphics and child-friendly spooky tunes which perfectly set the tone for a Halloween themed game. There is no voice acting and the dialogue boxes sometimes move a bit fast and you don’t get to press a button to advance them, which is weird, so you better get ready to read fast as well. The controls work OK on the keyboard + mouse but I highly recommend you use a controller only because it will make those pesky quick-time-events easier.

For a 30 year old dad who barely has time to play video games anymore, this is absolutely mouth-watering.

[h1] A super fun game [/h1]

61695947.review:
Very cute little turn-based RPG and a perfect game to introduce younger kids to the genre, I think.

Monsters are stealing all the Halloween sweets, and it's up to you and your newfound friends to stop them and rescue your kidnapped sibling! Complete sidequests to unlock new costume pieces, collect trading cards, and play hide and seek while beating up trolls and bird-men and tracking down the big bad. The turn-based combat is very easily grasped, as there isn't a lot of depth - there are basic attacks that are dealt by quicktime event (which will still do damage even if you fail), and a special attack or buff  unique to each costume that can be unleashed every few turns. Aside from maybe the late-game bosses, I don't think anyone is likely to have much difficulty in combat. A lot of the fun comes from trying out each costume as you unlock them to see which you like best (and there certainly are a lot of costumes to unlock).

The sidequests are fairly basic, mostly being completed automatically as a result of following the story, which involves moving from one area to another (your neighbourhood, the local shopping plaza, a showground, etc.) and battling all the monsters there to scare them into moving to the next location til you reach the boss. No crazy twists or anything, it's just a charming and sometimes silly little story about a bunch of kids saving Halloween.

[i]Costume Quest[/i] is not a long game - it took me about 6.5 hours to finish - but I'd say that's a point in it's favour. It's a charming experience, but not very deep, and I think would grow repetitive before long. But it's cute lighthearted fun, and I'd say is worth playing,


NB: The Grubbins on Ice DLC ends on something of a cliffhanger

Costume Quest is a short but extremely cute turn based RPG, You are a kid at halloween, Candy is the currency and costumes give you abilities. It really brings you into the mind of a 6 year old.

The Story is about little kids on Halloween, You are twins and you can pick if you want to play the brother or the sister, You need to collect candy in your robot costume while your sibling tags along in a candy costume, this soon turns into a Search and rescue mission when a candy stealing monster thinks your sibling is a real piece of candy.

Candy allows you to buy stuff, Like Stamps which give you stat boosts or other perks in combat, Some stamps can only be obtained by trading other stamps for it, But most of them are for sale at several NPCs, You gain candy by winning battles, Vandalizing property or just pick it up from the ground, Ofcourse you also gain candy by trick or treating, If a good guy opens up you get candy, If a monster opens the door you get into a battle directly.

Costumes do not only change your appearance, They give you special abilities while roaming like rocket skates, Lighting, Shielding, etc. In battles you transform into a real life version of your costume, Each costume has a basic attack and a charged attack which plays a little video when you use it. Some costumes have a third ability for healing or other special abilities. 

The game is very short, it will probably last you around 5 - 10 hours for full completion, But it is very astethicly pleasing and a rewarding experience, It is also very funny maybe a bit dark, But funny nonetheless.

The battle system is turn based, You use 1 ability or attack with each member of your party every turn. It is not really a challenge, But it still is pretty fun, Getting the right outfits, the right level and the right stamps can be vital to winning certain battles. 

The sidequests are fun, but they repeat themselfes each area, There is no realy challenge, And you will probably complete them without any effort by doing the main quests, This is something the game could have done better, More sidequests, Once you complete the main story there is not much more to do.

Overall the game is amazing, It is an absolute must have, it is a great experience, I have to give it an 9 out of 10, The game is perfect in so many ways, I just wish it had more replay value and more quests.

Costume Quest es un juego que me ha entretenido bastante y me ha parecido realmente bien ejecutado. No carece de algún que otro defecto, pero en general la experiencia ha sido tremendamente satisfactoria.

En el juego tomamos el rol de un niño, o una niña, los cuales son hermanos gemelos y acaban de llegar a la ciudad. Es la noche de Halloween y están disfrazados y preparados para salir a pedir caramelos por las distintas casas del barrio.

Sin embargo, nuestro gemelo será secuestrado por un monstruo en la primera casa que visitamos y ahí dará comienzo toda la aventura.

Costume Quest es un juego realmente original y muy entrañable. Todo en el juego está excelentemente representado y ambientado, recordando en cierto modo a las películas de aventuras de los años 80 que se basaban en esa fiesta.

Los niños paseando por el barrio disfrazados, esas casas típicas de barrio de clase media americano, esa música clásica de Halloween que hemos escuchado miles de veces… todo está ahí, muy bien representado y con un gran sentido del humor, además.

El sistema de juego es básicamente un JRPG de toda la vida al estilo clásico, pero algo más simplificado. Como tal iremos encontrándonos con enemigos en el mapa de exploración y al atacarlos, o al acercarnos demasiado a ellos, se pasará a una pantalla de combate donde podremos utilizar un ataque básico y uno especial llegado el momento.

El sistema funciona realmente bien, aún en su simpleza, pero sí es cierto que se puede volver algo repetitivo a medio plazo, algo a lo que no ayuda que sea tremendamente fácil toda la aventura.

La gracia del juego está en explorar los diferentes lugares por donde nos llevará nuestro periplo mientras buscamos a nuestro gemelo, llevamos a cabo misiones secundarias, coleccionamos cartas y compramos potenciadores que nos darán determinadas ventajas en combate.

Y mientras hacemos esto, iremos buscando diferentes piezas para crear más y más disfraces, a cada cual más original y divertido.

Esto de los disfraces es realmente importante, ya que los necesitaremos para poder seguir avanzando en la aventura y además nos servirán para variar en algo los enfrentamientos en combate, ya que cada uno de ellos tiene habilidades únicas.

Como he comentado, su punto más criticable es que es un juego realmente fácil. De hecho, yo no morí ni una vez de principio a fin, pero el juego es tan entretenido y está realizado con tan buen gusto, que eso pasa a un segundo plano totalmente. 

Sin duda, nuestros protagonistas, los gemelos, más otros compañeros que nos iremos encontrando por el camino, viven una aventura que a cualquiera de nosotros nos gustaría haber vivido con esa edad. Por lo que la simpatía hacia el juego está más que asegurada.

En esta versión de Costume Quest se incluye el juego base más una pequeña expansión de unas pocas horas, la cual es una aventura independiente que sucede después de los hechos acaecidos en la historia principal. 

La expansión no tiene al carisma ni el aire festivo que tiene la primera parte, aunque sigue siendo entretenida. Es un añadido que se agradece y alarga un poco la vida del juego.

En definitiva, Costume Quest es una aventura cuyo mayor defecto es su dificultad inexistente, pero tiene tantos aciertos jugables, es tan entretenido y tan original en su planteamiento, que hará que eso pase a ser algo sin demasiada importancia.

51090262.review:
This was easily a thumbs up or thumbs down. 

Costume Quest is a game developed by that company that released half-finished games. It's also by that company that has a quirky sort of aesthetic and releases games that have that sense of child wonderment that you'd see on a cartoon show. In a way, Costume Quest is [b]THE[/b] Double Fine game.

Costume Quest is a game about kids going trick or treating to collect candy, finding and wearing different costumes, and getting different abilities in battle as a result of said costumes. The story is that you and your sibling go out on Halloween night, only for one of them to wind up kidnapped by monsters due to their giant candy costume (monsters like candy). What results is you making friends with two children and chasing the monsters down via RPG battle mechanics. 

The venture is split into two realms: the world exploration and the RPG battles. The world exploration entails trick or treating at every home on the map in order to open a demon gateway that continues the story. When trick or treating at any home there is a delay in the door opening n anticipation of who is going to open the door. If it's a human, you get candy which can be used to buy battle stamps (which enhance battle abilities); if it's a monster you get a battle instead. Beyond trick or treating every house, you can walk around the map and talk to people roaming about. This comprises the sidequests.

The problem with the sidequests is that there are only around 4 of them, and they repeat on every map. There's always some kid that wants a specific stamp that you will get through a quest; 6 kids hiding that you have to find; a guy that wants you to participate in his bobbing for apples minigame. You will always get some manner of costumes on every map which have a battle ability and a world exploration ability.

...or rather, they always have a battle ability and only sometimes have a world exploration ability. It's a completely missed opportunity. Some abilities are only used once to get past 1 area. Others are so quest specific that they are absolutely useless outside of them. The majority of costumes don't even have world exploration abilities, which means that this segment of the game is even drier than you'd think. 

The battle system is even worse. At first I was excited as it takes Paper Mario queues whereby you press specific keys to increase attack power or to block and take reduced damage during either attack or defense animations. The problem is that literally your only options during any sort of encounter are to attack or run away. Every turn the only option is to attack, with your costumes special ability activating every 3 turns. Every battle lasted 6 turns or less. There is no variety in your attacks; the mech costume will always be a bar that fills where you press Y or X or A or B when it reaches a specific point. The statue is always circle the left stick. It never changes. It plays itself. Battles are agonizing after an hour. Utter waste of time.

Costume Quest has all the pieces. If there was something more to trick or treating; if the battle mechanics were VASTLY expanded; if the world exploration had more than 3 quests on repeat, we would have SOMETHING. Anyone that begins this game will love it in the first hour. The world is charming and the parts seem promising. I know I loved it. The novelty of the idea-the unique premise, it has so much potential. 

According to the developers this game only had a years worth of development time, with the team focusing on the bare essentials to get the game out. If this game lasted 1 hour it would be an easy recommendation. Luckily it lasts less than 5 hours, but that's an insult to the quality itself. Which leads me to a downvote. If a game lasting longer than half a workday is a plus then there is something fundamentally wrong with the package. This game can easily be recommended over its uniqueness. The writing is on point. The look and feel land it. 

It's just so damn empty and devoid of anything past bare, bare, [i]bare[/i] essentials. But that's the story of Double Fine nowadays. "Good ideas, great premise and unique cartoon feel; woefully unfinished ideas". We're talking about a developer that released a half finished game. Literally. I'm only upset because this game could be real good. It was an easy "above average" and recommendation for me. But playing the DLC and seeing the [i]same. exact. fu***ng. sh*t.[/i] completely turned this around to an almost 1/10 for me. I understand it had a short development time, but I also understand that the sequel is almost completely the same and has a ton of reused assets. They didn't even [b]bother[/b] to enhance the base they had. It's almost insulting. Almost, if I didn't expect it.

Fights are turn-based RPG fights where you can choose between normal attack, special item attack (if you have one equipped; this generally stuns targets) and a super move that unlocks every three turns and... that's it. You get a little customization on your end with what costumes you load, but some costumes are definitely better than others, and some of their features are badly integrated into the game (there's one costume that can hide a character, but you need to wait three turns to use it and it only lasts one turn, so it's really not worth your time, except for precisely one boss fight, which you wouldn't know until you're in the boss fight, where the game telegraphs who's going to get hit by a super attack).  In the end, you just to the same things over and over again to beat the opponents, and there are very few "interesting" fights.

The game is strongest with its side-quests, like the costume contest, or delving into the patriotic costume conspiracy, or rescuing rebellious grubbins.  If the game had been a quirky point-and-click adventure (what Double Fine excels at), I think I would have rated it higher; the gameplay feels more like padding on what makes the game fun.

It is not worth $10 bucks.  After watching the cartoon (which was fun!) I picked up both for $5, and that felt like a decent price.  I don't feel ripped off and, like I said, I had fun, but unless you're really into this sort of game, I would skip it. There are better "cute/weird JRPG" knock-offs. Costume Quest is a great little gem. It's a relatively simple turn based RPG based around Halloween, and in particular, a small set of kids who are going out trick or treating. Powers granted are based on the costume they wear, which are unlocked by collecting the different elements as you go through the game, with most costumes giving a different power. [h1]What you do:[/h1]
You play as one of two siblings while the other one gets nabbed by a monster while you're out trick or treating. This is a turn based RPG taking place in three Halloween-esque locations (and a fourth location as free DLC). The costume you start out with and the many costumes you can find throughout the game become personas you take on when you wear them. It doesn't matter who in your party wears the costume, they simply turn into the real thing of that costume when you enter battle, giving them different abilities. There are "timed" hits for regular attacks, and each costume has a unique special attack that charges up after three turns. For example, the robot costume gets a missile barrage attack that hits all enemies, while the knight gets a highly defensive shield he or she can place on another ally. You also get stamps which you can equip one to each party member to give them something extra like poison damage or a stun attack to paralyze an enemy. There are lots of treasure chest-like objects around filled with candy or specific costume materials. 
When you go trick or treating to people's houses, the people their will either be home and give you candy (currency) or a monster will be there who will start a fight with you (which gets you candy and experience points). The story is that monsters are secretly invading your world, and of course no one believes you, so you must rescue your sister by yourself with the help new friends you make along the way. Some costumes also have out-of-battle abilities which help you traverse the environment or solve puzzles. There are a good number of side quests and mini games to play as well for extra candy to buy stamps and costume pieces to gain new forms and abilities.

[h1]What I like:[/h1]
+ The premise of the game and environments are pretty cool and original. 
+ The party system with the costumes is a cool idea that allows you to customize your party's appearance and abilities.
+ I think the different environments are creative and fit the Halloween theme very well (neighborhood, mall, and fair grounds).
+ The extra DLC included for free takes place after the main game, in winter. This mode has it's own separate save files.
+ The inclusion of "timed hits" keeps the player engaged in turn-based battles to better attack and defend.
+ Great sense of humor for nerds.

[h1]What I don't like:[/h1]
- The game is so easy most of the way that you won't need to change off your starting costumes or form specific parties to meet certain challenges. I only made plans for the final boss.
- There a lot of auto moving dialog boxes. There's no voice overs, so I see no reason to take away my ability to progress the dialog when I'm finished reading it. I realized during the game that there is a cutscene pause button (weirdly X on xbox controller), so that was a compromise for my not-fast-enough reading speed.
- The mouse on PC is picked up automatically, so it will be center screen and highlight that option first on any menu until you start your file or move it.

[h1]Recommendation:[/h1]
The main game length is about 6 hours long and the DLC will add another 2 hours. The game is fairly easy, but has a good sense of humor and fun locations to explore.

Full review at: http://thegamehoard.com/2018/10/30/a-look-at-the-latest-costume-quest-pc/

Costume Quest is a charming and adorable Halloween adventure based around an incredibly creative idea of childrens’ homemade costumes turning into giant, cooler battle versions when they enter the game’s turn-based RPG battles. Much of the fun in the experience comes from the commitment to the theme and cute writing, and calling it some simple Halloween fun is accurate in another way. The battle system can have a bit of strategy to it, but its a bit too basic for how often you engage with it. It accommodates this well at times by making the player about as strong as their opponents, but it can’t completely escape how some of the fights boil down to executing a basic attack repeatedly and then a super attack. There’s more to do than just battles though, and the extra touches of trick-or-treating, bobbing for apples, and other little diversions mean it never stops being delightful.

When it comes to capturing that childhood joy of the Halloween holiday, Costume Quest does an excellent job. It’s a light-hearted and silly story designed to make you smile. It comes up a bit short in the combat design though, mainly because it only really has the minimal strategic considerations to give it depth, and those considerations don’t tend to deviate until something new like a boss is added to the picture. The battles aren’t pushovers because they are balanced appropriately, but your considerations during them are a bit too straightforward, even if you do decided to wear the stamps that give you the one extra attack. If every costume was just given one extra attack with a special ability, there could have been much more variety to the experience, but Costume Quest certainly has enough going for it to tap into the fun of the Halloween season.

Costume Quest takes the fun activities that kids love from the Halloween season and ties them to game mechanics that players of any age can enjoy. Even if you’re too old to trick-or-treat, maybe you can find some of the cheer children still find in it by playing a game that ties it to gameplay and cute storytelling that appeals to all ages.

At first, the game seems easy like it is impossible to lose, but the challenge does start to ramp up a little later on where you will want to take in consideration your party composition and timing when to use support abilities.  The graphics on the world is what you see for a majority of the screenshots, it's a cutsey style. But within combat, there's a brief sailormoon-esque transition sequence and you're transported into a comic-book style graphics for the combat and all the costumes suddenly look really amazing and cool! The starting robot costume is a great one to introduce the game.

There are collectibles to gather and most quests advance the story in someway or are easy to do along the way. For the halloween aspect - aside from the costimes - there is candy as currency, great jokes, and trick or treating which is a gamble -- is it a friendly encounter or time for a battle?

Game is about 5 hours in length to complete, it's short and sweet.
Some memorablie lines of dialog:
"I got the MANIFEST DESTINY" "You should see a doctor about that"
"Uh oh did that girl say she knows algebra?"

Here is a list to breakdown my thoughts on the game:
Pros:
- Great theme for a game (Halloween)
- Very imaginative characters/costumes which are swappble
- Great atmosphere
- Great humor
- Combat requires interaction similar to paper mario (i.e. press a button at right time to reduce/increase damage)

Neutral:
- Short, although I like that.
- Combat is pretty simple other than the paper-marioesqe interaction and doesn't really require too much thought outside of a few priority targets and some battles later on for support use
- You can choose your protagonist (Boy or girl twin)

Cons:
- Felt a bit lost at times on the map, especially in the beginning. There are times you have to keep talking to a NPC to progress but it's confusing since already talked to them , didn't realize their dialog changes after some more prompting.

[h1]TL;DR: If you're willing to rename files on your computer to make this work, you won't have a problem. If that sounds awful to you, skip Costume Quest.[/h1]

I want to like this game. I'm a fan of Doublefine's content. I love indie games, I love this game's aesthetic, and I played through both the base game and the DLC to the end. However, there's one glaring issue with the game that make me give it a thumbsdown:



[b][u]Costume Quest's new game plus feature doesn't work on Mac and Linux, years after release, and I had to resort to a community fix to make the new game plus feature work. That means the game doesn't actually work on Mac and Linux, and is falsely advertised.[/u][/b]



Costume Quest comes with DLC, "Grubbins on Ice", for "free" on Steam. I wouldn't call it "free" because you have to buy Costume Quest to access Grubbins on Ice. Therefore, it's just part of the game, and it should be usable content on Mac and Linux, given that Costume Quest is advertised as playable on Mac and Linux.

Grubbins on Ice utilizes a "new game plus" feature. For those unfamiliar, it means that you're supposed to be able to carry over items/stats/etc. from one game to another (either a new run of the same game, or a new run of a sequel) (example: Mass Effect series lets you carry characters over from Mass Effect to Mass Effect 2 to Mass Effect 3, I think).

However, on Mac and Linux, Grubbins on Ice does not properly start a "new game plus". Why? It looks for the wrong save file on your computer. Grubbins on Ice looks for "cq_dlc_save_0" but Costume Quest never generates that file, so you have to go into your files, copy your saved game, rename it "cq_dlc_save_0", start a new game in Grubbins on Ice, and the game finally works. (credit to kittenm4ster on the Steam forums for figuring this out, and MestreLion for providing details on how to make this work on Mac).

I was able to follow the instructions and fix this. However, look online, and you'll see that representatives from Doublefine promised that users that bought this game on Mac and Linux would have the issue patched. It's been years since they posted that promise, and it never happened. I played through the game in 2017 (it'd been sitting in my library for years, I think I got it in a Humble Bundle?) and the issue still hadn't been fixed, something that is probably super easy for Doublefine to fix given that the game is looking for the wrong file name, and that's the only issue.



Does this make the game unplayable? No. But, for 90% of the games I play, I don't have issues where I have to go muddle with my computer's files, and I don't have to look up esoteric game mechanics on the Internet to find out why a game that's advertised as so easy it's child-friendly isn't working as it should.


The game is charming, with cute graphics, although, the Grubbins on Ice DLC had various visual glitches for me. I don't know if this is due to the fact I had to follow outside instructions to force the DLC to load my old game to start the new game plus, whether it's a Mac specific issue (which is still the responsibility of the developer to account for), or what, but it was annoying. Namely, characters flickered, and there were issues with party AI, in that often times, the other characters in my party were lagging behind the main character, getting stuck in weird ways, etc.

Is this my last Doublefine game? No. I'm probably going to play Stacking after this. But I'm definitely annoyed with their poor customer service.

I'd say this is appropriate for ages 10+, because some of the animations may be too scary for younger children, and there's a stark difference between the overworld and battle art style. While I appreciate that as an adult, some younger kids may be scared by some of the animations of the enemies.

Costume Quest trades in item management and statistic tracking to focus more on mood and comedy. That's not to say there isn't an engaging RPG experience to be had here, it's just played a bit differently. You play as one of two siblings about to trick or treat on Halloween night. Whomever you pick, monsters mistake the other as a piece of candy because of their costume. 

Thus begins a quest against the crusty Grubblins to rescue your own flesh and blood to avoid being grounded. These goblin-like Grublins are attempting to steal all of the candy from the houses in the neighborhood. So, to progress, you guessed it, trick or treat your ass off! It's a gamble, sometimes theres a friendly neighbor looking to rid themselves of late night sweets, while other doors open to a battle against the grubblins.  

The battles are what set it apart from other RPGs. The various costumes you collect give you different abilities when worn into battle. They each have unique attacks and specials that charge during the battle. In addition, you collect Battle Stamps that give you various attacks and stat boosts for characters, which you may only equip one at a time. Despite how simple this system may sound, you are given a lot of freedom to create some interesting, fun, and dangerous combinations between costumes and stamps over the course of a full game. 

It's short though, clocking in at about ten hours for me after finishing up all of the loose ends. I had a good time. Running from house to house along jack-o-lantern lit streets really made it feel like October and I was reminded of my own childhood experiences.

There's nothing about Costume Quest that makes it extremely impressive. It's not the sort of game to end up on a game of the year list, and it's not the sort of game you show off to all your friends. Unlike most games i play, there isn't any super unique or innovative mechanic that really makes the game stand out from other rpg's, but it does enough to be above average.

The story is that on Holloween night you are a boy/girl who goes trick or treating with your brother/sister until he/she is kidnapped by monsters. Goblins not only want to eat your family member, but they want ALL OF THE CANDY. However you can stand up to them, thanks to the powers given to you by your Holloween costumes! Your goal is to go on an adventure meeting new kids and going all around town in order to chase down the monsters and save your sibling!

The actual combat is the classic turn based combat formula. You take to the field using the power of whatever costume your wearing to tear down those ruthless baddies! This time it has been has been given a twist, badges and quick time events! This reminded me a lot of Paper Mario TTYD (like my #1 game of all time), but the quick time events are less precise than paper marios and if you don't use more than the basic moveset it becomes extremely repetetive. This is where badges come in to add variety to your game, except the badges are mostly uninteresting stat boosts that do very little to change up how you play (unlike Paper Mario where the badges completely defined your playstyle). I found the combat engaging enough to hold my interest throughout the game; it falls into the same pitfall most turn based combat does where all your abilities feeling too similar and achieve the same goal. Combat is not Costume Quest's strong suit.

The atmosphere of the game is fantastic. There's this childrens bedtime story vibe to the whole game that i found really fitting because the entire story feels like a kid playing pretend. From the costumes giving you powers to the adults not seeing monsters, the game has this make-believe quality where you half think the whole game is a facade but you're caught up in sillyness of it all so you don't care. 

What i enjoyed most in the game was just exploring the world. Throughout the multiple zones you have a costumes and candy (and monsters) to discover through exploration and use of your super powers. The game makes good use of the Holloween setting. Every zone has houses to trick or treat at, and each house can either give you a candy giving adult or an evil monster who will want to fight. If you pick this game up pay attention to the dialog and talk to as many NPC's as you can because it'll give you a good chuckle. There's all sorts of cute characters to talk to, all of whom set a contrast to the spooky monsters.

The game isn't going to do anything to blow your mind, and that's ok. With everyone running around the indie market trying to be the next Bastion, i enjoy these games that focus on being cute and fun. If what i've written sounds pleasent, give Costume Quest a try and see if you'll like it.

34788631.review:
Costume Quest is one of the amazing games that came out of Double Fine's Amnesia Fortnight. A traditional turn based RPG with a Halloween concept and smart writing, Costume Quest is perfect for all ages. This game comes with a free DLC called Grubbins on Ice.

[h1]Story[/h1]

Depending on who you choose, you play as either Reynold or Wren. The twins are hyped to go out and trick-or-treat but a monster ends mistaking one of the siblings as a large piece of candy and kidnaps the child. With the help of a cat(?) who may or may not have given your character special powers through his/her costume, your character goes off on a quest to save his/her sibling with friends he/she makes on the way, and maybe, in the process of doing so, end up saving Halloween.

Costume Quest's story is fairly adequate but it is bolstered by stellar writing filled to the brim with traditional Double Fine humour. Expect to chuckle often while playing this game.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

Costume Quest is a turn based RPG lite. It's very simplistic in execution, and gets the job done. Do not expect huge skill trees or deep mechanics - there are none in this game. You can do additional damage or reduce damage taken by doing QTEs with very generous timings, and you have 'Battle Stamps' that give you passive bonuses like dealing additional damage. Your characters are also healed automatically after every battle. There are no random encounters in this game (aside from the monsters that you encounter while trick-or-treating). Costume Quest has boss battles that are quite fun indeed.

Outside of combat, you play in fixed camera hub worlds, trick-or-treating at various houses or bashing various environmental objects to get candy. You can use candy to buy new Battle Stamps to make your character even stronger, however, each character is only allowed to equip one Battle Stamp at a time. After you trick-or-treat all the houses in a given hub, you are allowed to pass through the Monster Gate that blocks your progress to the next hub and this repeats several times till you reach the end of the game.

Each costume your characters wear provide them with various powers in battle. The Statue of Liberty costume plays a traditional healer role while the Space Warrior is a pure melee character. Some of your costumes also have environmental effects - the main character can use the Shield ability to block falling debris while wearing the Knight Costume, while the Robot costume can allow you to quickly Boost yourself so that you can dash around through the environment. You'll need your costumes to not only fight, but also make it through the various obstacles you encounter in each hub, all the while collecting candy and Creepy Treat cards, doing quests, and finding various pieces of costumes that will help you in your adventure.

This is a very easy game, and one should expect a playthrough to be between 4-6 hours. The additional DLC chapter, Grubbins on Ice, is another hour or two of gameplay.

[h1]Visuals[/h1]

Costume Quest has a very charming art style and is definitely easy on the eyes. The small scenes that precede battes where your character transforms into a giant sized, realized version of the costume he/she is wearing is really good and well animated. 

However, the game doesn't run all that well technically. It's sufficient but a game like this shouldn't be having difficulties running at a solid 30 or 60 FPS. There are bits of slowdown, most noticeably in the scene where you are trick-or-treating. This is not a big deal in battles, fortunately.

[h1]Audio[/h1]

On the aural front, Costume Quest is not a winner. None of the music in this game is memorable or even good.  I can't comment on the voice acting in this game because it has none. Sound effects do their job.

[h1]Overall[/h1]

Costume Quest is a must-play, fun game that is perfectly paced - just before the signs of repetition even kick in, the game ends. Clever writing and tons of heart make this game perfect for every age. If you see this game on sale, be sure to snap it up. My only regret is I didn't play this game on Halloween. Oh well.

[h1]Note to Prospective Buyers[/h1]

The game was an ~600 MB download on Steam. 

Costume Quest works on Windows 10. Word of caution : DO NOT ALT+TAB OUT OF THIS GAME; Alt+Tab will result in a crash, almost always.

Costume Quest has Steam Trading Cards.

PRO TIP : You can skip the short scene that plays when you get into a battle by pressing Shift.

[h1]Note to Achievement Hunters[/h1]

This game is very easy to 100%, and you can do so in a single playthrough.
