Costume Quest easily became one of my favorite turn-based RPGs.

It's Visuals are really amazing to look at, the cartoonish cute graphics with the halloween theme combined really fits well.

The Story is simple but also unique, you play as one of the twins getting dressed up to trick or treat around the neighborhood, but the other twin gets kidnapped by a bunch of monsters and you need to rescue him/her. The game also has some pretty good dialouge for some of the interactions.

The Gameplay is something you don't see every so often in other turn-based RPGs (again, it's simple and unique). Since it's a halloween game, the game has a clever mechanic when you go trick or treating in a door, you have a 50% to get a battle (Trick) or someone who gives you an amount of candy (Treat). Instead of getting different party members like in most RPGs, you collect Costume Pieces in which you need to complete the set to get the full costume. Each costume gives you different abillities for battle or exploration, you can switch costumes for the 3 characters in the game which basically switches their roles. There's also Battle Stamps that you can buy with candy which enhances your characters with special atributes. The battles are basically what you get in other RPGs; you have Attack, Super, Special Abilites if you have specific Battle Stamps, and Run Away. The combat system is similar to those in Mario RPG games but much easier, where you can do a specific command to do more damage than your normal attack or to lower your damage taken. After battles, you gain XP, Candy to buy more Battle Stamps and sometimes Creepy Treats Cards.

While the game is great, it also has it's downsides. Game is locked at 30 FPS and there is no available way to disable that, combat can be a bit repetitive, some parts are really dark and can't see really anything (even though some of those parts you need the Space Suit), there's only one Minigame: The Apple Bobbing one, Candy can only be used for Battle Stamps,
the maximum level is 10 (Main Game) and 14 (Grubbins on Ice Expansion), and the game is a bit short as i beat the game 100% in just 7 Hours (5 in Main Game, 2 in Grubbins on Ice Expansion) with no Replay Value.

Even though it has it's problems, i have to say that with it's nice-looking artstyle, good story and unique gameplay mechanics, this game is a must-buy for RPG fans that want something fresh and simple, and if you're new to RPGs, pick up this game, it's short but it's still a great game to enjoy.

Costume Quest is a silly roleplaying game with a Halloween theme. You play as either Wren or Reynold, a young kid who needs to rescue their kidnapped sibling and stop the invading monsters from stealing all the Halloween candy.

[h1]Visuals[/h1]
The visuals are rather cute and adorable. Unfortunately the game has a lot of technical problems. First of all, the game has an extremely annoying 30 FPS lock that doesn't even work properly and that makes all the animations look choppy.

Furthermore, the game does not properly support 16:10 resolutions and some of the UI elements will appear partially outside the screen.

[h1]Audio[/h1]
The game has a decent enough sound track and the sound effects are pretty good too. There's no voice acting.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
The gameplay in Costume Quest is pretty dreadful. The exploration aspects are passable but rather repetitive. You wander around the maps, looking for houses to trick and treat and simple quests to complete.

It is the combat, however, that is truly terrible. This is probably the worst RPG combat I have ever seen. It's the traditional turn-based JRPG combat with all the depth and choice removed. And to add insult to injury, every single action will require you to complete a tedious QTE. To make matters even worse, the encounters are extremely repetitive and even the bosses are generally quite simple.

The ability to change your Halloween costume (and unlock different special powers) is a nice touch, but not nearly enough to make up for the otherwise weak gameplay.

[h1]Difficulty[/h1]
The game is quite easy and only a couple of the bosses provide any real challenge.

[h1]Controls[/h1]
The controls are passable on a gamepad but by no means great. The constant QTEs in combat are extremely tedious and the fixed camera can be a major pain while exploring.

[h1]Story and Writing[/h1]
The story is rather silly and childish. This wouldn't really be an issue by itself, but unfortunately the quality of the writing is quite low, especially for a Double Fine game.

[h1]Bugs and Glitches[/h1]
Overall the game was reasonably bug free. However, the quest for recovering your stolen costumes appeared quite glitchy and it took quite a few attempts to complete.

[h1]Final Verdict[/h1]
I found Costume Quest a pretty bad game overall and it is easily my least favorite Double Fine game so far. The cute visuals are nowhere near enough to make up for the utterly dreadful and repetitive gameplay. Definitely not recommended.

I played through the main campaign in around 5 hours.

[h1][b]★★★☆☆[/b][/h1]
I almost feel bad for not joining the love the people - including friends and family - share for Double Fine and so also for this game, because I don't think this is perfect. I think its the best looking Double Fine game to date, with its very refined cell-shaded graphical style, but I think it's just too easy, and too short. Perhaps that's what this game is not [i]about[/i], as it seems that the festive atmosphere and the charm the world inherits from what Double Fine games are known for.

My problem is that it's a short game that feels long, in a bad way. Of the 7 hours I spent playing this game (including the DLC), I felt like I was watching the same 3 battles play over again and again, without any feeling of commitment since the battles are so easy and simple. Each character has one  basic attack and a special attack that is usable in the 3 turn. But by the time I can use it, I most likely don't even need to use it, since one basic attack is enough to be succesful. You do get the option to add another action, like stunning or poisoning, but I found those not necessary, even after using them. In fact, I used the buffs that would increase attack power and the ability to counterattack so the fights are over within 2 or 3 turns.

Another small quirck, that some other reviewers also mentioned, is the fast-crolling, automated dialogues (though, mostly just in cutscenes). The is no voice-acting, but only texts. The problem that you can easily miss parts of the text when you're destracted at all. I don't read fast or slow, but I was still somewhat annoyed with this text speed.

Despite the lack of difficulty and the monotonous combat, I still enjoyed the game for the look and character. Try it out when you feel like taking a break a night or two from the stress you might endure from your regular life.

Edit: during a sale you can get this game (including the DLC) for a mere 1 buck. Though I wouldn't recommend this for a full 10 bucks, I do think it's definitely worth it for such a low price.

29281187.review:
Costume Quest is a game that unexpectedly won me over completely. While I still have not played all of Double Fine's games yet, this particular game is near the top for me, and also one of my favorite games in general for recent years.

There is a lot of heart in the design and story of Costume Quest, which is a wonderfully funny kids' adventure. You begin the game on Halloween night for a brother and sister, which quickly evolves into a gigantic quest beyond any normal realm, as you must fight monsters that sweep in to take over the night.

As a whole, Costume Quest is indeed a quest. As you control a set of kids going on their adventure throughout the game, you will do a variety of things from actual trick-or-treating to exploration for hidden items to performing role-playing battles. The game is indeed an RPG with main and side quests, special equipment and power-up items, along with general collectibles. Most fitting to the game is that candy is your currency.

Each new area that you enter, you generally must trick-or-treat at a set number of houses or doorways. When doing so, you will literally get a trick or a treat. The treat is simply candy, as expected. The trick, however, is a fight with the monsters that are the main enemies of the game. When battles launch up, your characters have mini-cutscenes where they turn into the beings that they are wearing as costumes, e.g., a robot will suddenly stand up very tall and be prepared to fight.

The style of the battles are turn-based, though you only have three options - normal attack, special power, and Battle Stamp power. When you perform normal attacks, each costume has a different style of "timing" that you can use to perform extra damage if you hit the right buttons in the proper manner. Special powers cannot be used until enough energy (essentially MP) is accrued, which will generally happen after a few turns in battle. Battle Stamps are part of the equipment of the game, where each character can wear a single stamp to add extra strength or a new capability. Some of the Battle Stamps just affect stats, like increasing attack power. Others will give an ability for that third battle option, such as stunning enemies temporarily.

As can be seen both in and out of battle, the game has a very interesting, 3D cartoon art style showcasing the environment and characters. As already mentioned above, the battles have mini-cutscenes related to the costumes, and there are also special effects for the power attacks or for certain bosses that you fight along the way. Altogether, everything truly screams Halloween. Even the costumes that you are wearing will allow you to perform different capabilities in the "real" world, as you will need to switch between them to access certain areas or complete side quests on the map.

The story itself is also very well-done, having both a cheesy style but also a mapped-out purpose. As you continue through the game, you will learn more information about the beings that you are fighting against and what their end goal is. Take note that once you finish the game, the story is not done. The game has a free "Grubbins on Ice" DLC which continues from the end of the game. And even further, there is a Costume Quest 2 which continues from the endpoint of that DLC.

I highly recommend this game to just about any person. The adventure of the children is filled with fun, charm, humor, and a number of other qualities, combined into a very enjoyable game.

29229427.review:
[h1] Game Summary: [/h1] 
I really enjoyed this game because it captures so much of the Halloween spirit, which so often seems slighted and ignored in favor of Christmas.  This holds especially true for us adults, who don't get much to do on Halloween, unless we have kids of our own or we go to a bar or club.  Starting off, I'd say what supports this Halloween vibe so well is the inclusion of so many Halloween activities.  There's a bobbing for apples mini-game, collectible spooky cards you collect and trade for, using simple household items to build costumes, community events such as a costume contest, dealing with a random bully/jerk, and of course going Trick-or-Treating. I don't think they left anything out, unless you're a house egger and TP'er!  Throw in an unconventional bad guy who wants to steal mountains of candy for himself (ever hear of Wal-Mart, Jack?), and you have the basis for a kid-friendly and festive, turn-based RPG.  


[h1] Pros: [/h1] 
•	The different costumes you assemble provide different mechanics and features in battle.  Over time, you'll discover personal favorites, based on whether you prefer hitting the right button fast enough as it flashes on-screen, or timing your attack as the cursor slides over the bar.  Admittedly, some seem more powerful and useful than others, such as the vampire.  
•	I thought it was fun going to random doors, not knowing if you would receive a treat, in the form of gobs of candy (was never like that when I was a kid), or a trick, in the form of a fight.  It's a clever variation on having random battles.  
•	You get to pick between being the boy or girl, without one or the other being eye candy. *pun intended*  Seriously, it's kind of annoying when one or the other is hot, as if that should be a decisive factor.  Just let me be sexist!
•	Battles are fairly straightforward and simple, though all the costume choices and their respective special abilities is something you'll have to factor in as you set up your equipment. 
•	Considering you're just going trick-or-treating on Halloween, the gameplay is reasonably long, at around eight hours.  
•	The game has fun, witty dialogue, motivating players to explore and talk with NPCs.
•	Enemies don't respawn, so there's no grinding for levels in the game.  


[h1] Cons: [/h1] 
•	Navigating the map can be annoying, but it makes more sense over time.  Having the robot roller skates on to zip around at turbo speed helps with this and is a nice touch, since most RPGs have you plod around at a constant, slow pace.  However, you have to play as the robot to use them.  
•	Some fights were hard to get through, since I'd need to avoid making any mistakes (especially when fighting three baddies at once).  If they beat just one of my characters, I couldn't win the fight at all.  
•	The game takes place at night, for obvious reasons, which can make it hard to see clearly.  
•	The 3D graphics are alright, but they're not particularly compelling.  
•	I can't decide whether I find the story to be corny or creative.  


[h1] Conclusion: [/h1] 
Overall, I would recommend this game.  After you beat it, there's little reason to come back for a second playthrough, but I was charmed and had fun throughout my time playing it.  I did hit a few snags earlier on in the game, getting lost and mixed up trying to find secrets and items while navigating the neighborhood.  There were also some basic battles that required everything to go just right, or else the enemies would wipe out one of my characters and create an unwinnable fight.  I definitely think the game needed some better balancing in that regard.  However, once I got past those nuances and flaws, which I'm glad I persisted through, the rest of the game was a pleasant treat, instead of a dirty trick.

28235357.review:
Costume Quest is a cute little Halloween themed casual adventure game. This fun game had you teaming up with newfound friends to rescue your sister and save Halloween from candy-hunting monsters. The game feels like it was made for a younger audience, but certainly enjoyable by the young at heart.

[b]The graphics[/b] were really nicely done. It was appropriately cartoony, which fit the game quite well. All the animations and movements felt really smooth. Each level of the game was set in a unique setting which the art represented well.

[b]Story[/b] isn't the main focus of the game, but it is there. It's quite cute, fun and appropriate. There are certainly a couple of nods and winks in there and there's some enjoyable dialogue too.

[b]Gameplay[/b] was simplistic, requiring you to complete a number of quests on each level, all revolving around collecting candy, battle cards (which would give characters a boost in combat) and collectable trading cards. While each level was in a different setting, the gameplay felt a little too much like a copy of the level before it and that made it a tad boring. There were some unique activities on each level, I feel that more variety from level to level would have made it feel more fresh.

[b]Combat[/b] was very simplistic. Depending on which character's turn it was, it would either require a timed button press of one of four keys, a single button press or a mashing of one or more keys. Every third attack by a character had the options of choosing a special attack. Defence used a similar mechanic. I believe the simplicity of the combat can be attributed to a combination of the younger target audience as well as a relic of it being a console port. A Paper-Scissors-Rock style strength/weakness system would modify the damage given/received. The problem with this simplified approach is that after a while, it becomes rather repetitive. Costume Quest is one of my favorites - unique and dripping with the innocence of halloween most of us are too old to experience anymore, it's the type of game that makes you smile on its premise and presentation alone. Throw in fun - if simple - game mechanics, good humor, endearing characters and a plot out of a saturday morning cartoon: it's a really good package, and as something I can replay every year, it's more-than worth the TEN dollar asking price.

At its core it's a super simple turn-based RPG, but even its RPG mechanics have fun mechanics much like those from the original Paper Mario. You can fare better in battle with timed button presses to increase damage and defense. There are battle stamps that work like the badges from Paper Mario, which give each character a boost or a special command. It's really not that deep, but the fights are just difficult enough to require some kind of strategy. Not because they're complex or anything, but because the enemies will simply overpower you with force if you don't have a battle stamp equipped and aren't successful with the timed button presses.

For example - the Statue of Liberty costume has a special attack (which charge up through using regular attacks) that heals the party a small amount. It's a very small amount, but it can make or break a fight. The game is good about pitting you against enemies that are just a little bit tougher than your party, so you can't just breeze through them. There are also no random battles: all enemies appear on the screen, unless you meet them through trick-or-treating, and they don't regenerate - so there is a set number of battles per zone. This works well with the mechanics, as there are set items and experience you earn from the enemies you fight. That means you really must fight every enemy in the zone to get the full amount of experience, candy (currency) and items afforded to you. 

You move between transitional dungeons and hub zones, where you have to trick-or-treat at houses or stores to progress through the story. You won't be able to do that all right away, though - you'll need to do random quests for kids around the zones, collect candy, bob for apples, trade stuff, and find parts to make new costumes which grant you new field abilities, so you can progress further. The zones are really detailed and oozing with character - they're fun to run around and don't usually outstay their welcome. My only gripes are without a map, it can be hard to find that one last house you need to trick-or-treat at to progress the story, or that one last enemy you need to fight. Also some of the dungeons drag on a little bit - but as I write below, if you're finding the game to drag, you probably just need to take a break.

The plot is simple - your sister is kidnapped and you have to find her. There are goblins running around, but the adults think they're just kids in costumes. The goblins want candy for some reason, there's a main villain witch, etc. etc. It's really cute, and serviced by some great humor. The game is almost south-parkian in the way that the kids have gotten over their heads in a very real situation to which the adults are totally oblivious. It makes it funnier when the adults names are all literally "grown up". 

Costume Quest is a game to play in small spurts, as otherwise the mechanics will begin to get repetitive and you'll lose sight of the charm and atmosphere that makes the game so enjoyable. When I say repetitive, I mean the combat and actual field exploration can, yes, get really samey. It's best to play maybe half a zone at once and then take a break. You really owe it to this game and yourself to enjoy every minute of it, and that can't happen if you're just going through the motions. 

Costume Quest is a gem. It captures the feel of Halloween perfectly and if you're in the right mood, it can make you feel like a kid again. Like you really are out trick-or-treating with some friends, in a world of make-believe. Buy this, play it (during halloween), and then play the Grubbins on Ice DLC (that comes with it) during Christmas. 

I haven't actually played the Grubbins on Ice DLC yet, but I've heard great things about it. Albeit - it's a short little extra side-story that only take a few hours.

It's no secret that people enjoy spooking themselves throughout October. Some may dabble into the horrific imagery, the classic monsters, the eldritch horrors or the psychological drama of fear. All of these qualities are what many would consider as connotations of Halloween.

Halloween for me, however, has never been about the scares. While I may sound to be admiring the commercialism itself, I've always been reminded of Trick-or-Treating, Halloween cartoons/specials, and of the creativity/love for the holiday, especially the costumes. These are the qualities adults and kids alike treat themselves to every year.

These sentiments are why I find myself revisiting Costume Quest as a tradition. It provides a light-hearted, four to six hour adventure (with the DLC and all the extra quests) that captures the qualities I enjoy the most. Its shortened length and kid-like spectacle perfectly shows the forgotten fondness we have for the holiday of fears.

[h1]Something "Wicked" This Way Comes[/h1]

CQ itself has nothing unique that hasn't been seen in TV specials, movies or games. Its set-up is that you play as the brother/sister of a family, and you must rescue your sibling from the clutches of an evil witch bent on taking over Halloween with all the candy. (Also possibly not to get grounded). 

However, what the plot lacks in originality, the game's humor and execution provide something that shows its charm for being derivative of all the things kids and adults love about Halloween. 

If you grew up in the '90s like myself, then you probably are familiar with the trick-or-treat game from Cartoon Network. You walked around an small map with magical costumes, collecting candy from doors and obstacles in a time-limit for high-scores. 

Costume Quest shares the basic idea of a magical realism setting where the costumes themselves provide supernatural powers for kids. Instead of a competitive, high-score game, CQ is a traditional JRPG game with Paper Mario-like mechanics and various HUB maps to explore.

Compared to the Cartoon Network game, the maps are much larger along with providing mini-games and alternative quests for hidden rewards. Outside of combat, every costume provides an ability that varies in its utility. The quests are basic fetch or talk quests, and the level-design is a linear set of checkboxes given some player freedom to wander off. You won't be breaking the game's order of events or getting late-game costumes early.

When in combat, the kids transform themselves into a larger-than-life representation of their costume in what can be thought of as a Power Rangers mech fight. Enemies' designs are dramatized as well to make the combat more visually interesting than watching a blue-box robot fighting demons in bath-robes. That visual alone is how the fighting mechanics should be thought of: Absurd and simple.  

Like Paper Mario, the turn-based battles are broken up by quick-time-events that add/lower the damage you deal. The player's team and the enemy's take turns trading hits, and while you are on the defensive you can block attacks to lessen the blow. Some costumes have unique abilities like the Knight's Shield (defense buff), the Robot's Missle Barrage and the Lady Libery's Anthem (healing skill). 

To say that the combat system is basic would be stating the obvious. There are eleven costumes in the main game, and three new ones in the DLC. Each costume has its one-tailored playstyle and set of skills, separated by one of three costume types like rock-paper-and-scissors, and they each provide enough lasting appeal to keep the game from getting too stale with a limited roster. The game knows its combat isn't its greatest suit, so the variety and short length go a long way to keep the monotonous gameplay as low as possible.

[h1]There's Only 364 Days Til' Next Halloween[/h1]

As far as the game's other problems, if the game's charm doesn't sell you on it right away, then the gameplay, in and out of combat, won't sell you on the rest of the experience. 

The writing isn't Double Fine's best as it relies a lot on tropes, especially the protagonist and his/her companions, but the subversions from the player's character towards not carrying about the plot helps mitigate that issue. (Kind of like how Doomguy doesn't care about the plot in his recent game.) This is something the DLC as well as CQ2 fail to grasp as the plot relies on characters explaining the techno babble of wormholes. Neither one captures the same charm as the original. 

While Costume Quest is certainly not one of Double Fine's greatest successes it is an experience I would easily recommend to others. Usually I would have something more profound to say to end a review but CQ is simply a decent game.  It's nothing innovative in its gameplay, story or even its basic idea, but the way everything comes together nicely makes me longing for next Halloween to replay it again.

"Costume Quest" is a fine opportunity to get into the Halloween mood. Or even deeper.

It is a one-player RPG game involving two twin siblings getting separated by candy-greedy monsters from Repugia and two friends of theirs. So one sibling gets kidnapped and the other three children (including you as the twin brother or sister) set off for the rescue while fighting monsters, bosses and having fun by collecting Halloween stuff (costumes, candy, candy cards, battle stamps) and solving quests that get in your way.

The gameplay: Most of the time you will walk around places like your hometown or the town's mall and search for items and quests. All of these help you progress in the story and getting stronger. One quest you must complete a couple of times in order to progress is to knock on every available door to ask for treats. Either you just get them or have to battle a monster (that has occupied this house). 
So the other part of the game are the battles. The children use their costumes they've achieved (pumpkin, black cat, vampire, statue of liberty, etc...) and their special powers to fight the different monsters. And because it's an RPG you wait for your characters' turns and choose the actions they're suppoused to do now while the monsters get their turns, too. You can loose battles but never die. You just would have to try again. Every win is rewarded with experience points, candy and other items.
During all this you have your note book with you in which you have an overlook of your status, quests (and their status), costumes (with description), candy cards and a variety of battle stamps which can be used for battle by your characters.

I found "Costume Quest" very playable, the controls are easy to learn (and they're changeable if you really can't operate with them). I played with the keyboard and it worked just fine. It's a fun RPG with a good mixture of exploring, collecting and fighting. It's also easy to play, so also RPG beginners shouldn't have trouble to finish this game sooner or later.

The cartoonish 2.5/3D graphics are mostly sweet and lovely designed, that goes especially for the settings you go to.  They're colourful but not rainbow puking bright, they mostly match the Halloween season. When it goes to the characters, I find the children, their battle characters and the monsters were designed okay. I can't say that about the adult characters who either look like obese puppets, lifeless big-nosed humans or stick figures with grotesque heads and faces. They don't only look strange but also quite lifeless. I wished that a bit more effort would have went into their designs. But to the game's credit: the adults play a very minor role compared to the children.

The sound is so-so: I enjoyed the musical score very much. But the sound? It completely containts sound effects (which are fine), no voices (outside the occesional grunts of monster characters and human background mumbling in more crowded places). This means that the dialogues are all text bubbles and there are even no simple sounds expressed by the characters, wether a "Gasp!" or "Huh?" or "Ouch" or something. I find this negative since at least a bit of voice acting brings extra life to these characters but here, everybody is totally quiet. 

What about extras? There are achievements, trading cards, one minigame about apple bobbing and there is also an additional chapter included called "Grubbins on Ice" that goes on right after the story of the main game. I can't say it's that exciting or so much fun, you practically do the same things and collect new costumes but without Halloween going on. Still, it's worth for a bit of fun and the achievements.

So, can I recommend "Costume Quest"? Yes, absolutely. It's a sweet, fun game all around Halloween and the fantasy of children celebrating it. If you can't stand Halloween or just don't care about it, then I guess this shouldn't stop you from trying but you might have less joy with that game.
And if you're into RPGs or starting this, you definitely should check it out.

Though the main idea is to rescue someone, and though that's not very original in stories these days, it was a well told story that kept me very entertained. Graphics: Though I'm not a huge fan of cel style animation, I was extremely pleased with this medium with this game. Too many details would have ruined the power of the children's imagination and the softer non-detailed aspect of cel animation felt like it lent power to the story rather than taking away from it.

7.5/10

Pros
- Just oozes style and charm, with a great Halloween theme
- Very polished finished product
- Enjoyable timing-based combat (think Paper Mario)
- A large number of playable “characters” (13 combat costumes + 1 noncombat)
- Funny at times
- Includes the DLC episode for free

Cons
- Not a lot of variety in the locations or enemies (3 main story levels + 1 DLC level)
- Fairly short for an RPG (about 8 hours to finish)
- Simplified RPG combat leads to very few options and a lot of repetition
- The story isn’t exactly gripping
- Very linear

I actually really enjoyed this game.  It’s a very simple and short turn-based RPG that hit a lot of the right notes.  It just has a certain charm to it that is hard to describe. The combat contains a timing-based component where if you perform the correct action at the right time, your attacks will do more damage or you will take less damage on defense.  This helps keep you engaged in all of the battles.  Thankfully this component was included, because otherwise you have very few options in combat (attack, use a special if it is charged, or use a battle stamp which gives a combat ability).  In terms of battle stamps, these are reusable and basically replace items in the game, and can either confer an ability in combat (e.g. stun a single enemy) or a passive ability (e.g. more health).  The other source of variety in combat is the inclusion of 13 different combat costumes, each of which have their own abilities and play style (single target DPS, AoE, defense, healer, etc.).  That being said, even with these additions the combat can still drag at times.  Fighting a limited variety of enemies in the same environment over and over can become tedious.  Overall most battles are quite easy, but a few boss battles require strategy when selecting which battle stamps and costumes to use.  The story doesn’t contribute much, but the writing is good and there are some funny moments.  If you enjoy RPGs that don’t take themselves too seriously, this is a good game.  In addition, the simplified and streamlined nature of the game would make it a good option for someone who is new to RPGs or a younger gamer.

In the glorious words of the immortal Ernest P. Worrell I bring you these words of advice.. "Pretty soon the kids won't have to worry about eating their Brussel sprouts because the Brussel sprouts will be eating them."

Exchange the word Brussel sprouts with candy corn and you'll understand the game of Costume quest, a cute Halloween themed adventure game from the wonderful team at Double Fine entertainment.  The same group responsible for such classics as Psychonauts and Brutal Legend [b](Jack Black playing a rock and roll roadie.... YES PLEASE)[/b]  In this game you play as Reynold and Wren a pair of twins who have recently moved to a new neighborhood, it's Halloween night and they are planning on going trick or treating.   After selecting which sibling you want to control, either Wren, the 10 minute older sister or Reynold the 10 pound heavier member of the dynamite duo, you are shipped off into the world.  The selected sibling gets a Robot custom, the other gets dressed as a piece of Candy Corn..  Social norms be damned if you pick the female character..  who says females aren't into Robots :-D  certainly not me.

[b]  (It was here where the first bit of disbelief struck me, the parents allowed their twin children to leave the house unaccompanied to go trick or treating in a new neighborhood.  These are two children who appear to be 8 - 9 years old, wandering the streets of a new neighborhood on Halloween night which is a night when child predators are normally tremendously on the prowl looking for victims.  Furthermore, after the sibling you didn't pick gets literally kidnapped, instead of running home, or screaming for help  or literally anything we've been teaching children to do for the last 30 years, they decide to go on a crazy adventure to find the sister to avoid punishment.  Just a quick note, a police officer is literally a twenty or thirty feet away away from the abduction site...)  soap box off[/b]

After trick or treating at the first house, the pair try a second, only this time the candy corn gets abducted by a candy stealing grubbin monster...  OH MY!!!..   So off we go on an adventure to rescue our sister/brother from the clutches of a nasty candy stealing evil corporation, I'm talking a really dirty nasty organization we haven't seen in video games since Umbrella corporation..   Along the way to rescue your sibling you meet new friends, discover a sinister plot to steal candy, and defeat some monsters making for an amazing Halloween adventure which can be enjoyed at any time of year.

[h1] The Story [/h1]

I pretty much described the story above, siblings, candy, stealing, adventure.  The story takes place in three locations, Auburn Pines, which is the starting neighborhood, Autumn Haven Mall (easy enough it's a Mall), and Fall Valley carnival, each area offers up the chance to explore, trick or treat, bob for candy apples, defeat monsters and oh yeah... get that sweet, sweet candy baby.. nuff said!!!

[h1] The Gameplay [/h1]

The first aspect the gamer is introduced to is trick or treating, which is just as it sounds, you go up to a house, knock on the door and wait for a trick (battle) or a trick (candy)  It's as simplistic as that.  Knocking on doors isn't the only way to collect candy, numerous interactive objects in the environment such as mailboxes, trashcans, shrubs, etc etc etc, can be pounded on by your candy pail in an attempt to wriggle loose a few extra pieces of candy, also numerous areas have candy thrown about on the ground... [b] I personally wouldn't pick up candy off the ground and eat it, but hey whatever floats my characters boat[/b].  The game features three types of collectibles, the first is Costumes, you start with the Robot costume, and soon after acquire a knight outfit, others you can collect are the statue of liberty, a unicorn, french fries and many more.  Many of the costumes have two special benefits, the first being an extra ability you can use while out of combat, like the Robot which can travel faster, or the Knight, that can shield from falling items.  The second ability is a special battle ability, whether it's rockets, a shield of protection or a powerful group heal.  

The second type of collectible in the game are battle cards, these cards can be used to further enhance your character, give them additional HP, defense, a stun, etc etc etc, you can buy the cards from Sadie using the candy you collect during your adventure.  With each new area, additional cards are added for you to buy, the new cards offer upgrades over the older cards.  These are very useful in helping to gain the advantage in your battles to come.  The final collectibles are called treat cards, these resemble trading cards, they really serve no purpose, outside of being necessary to complete a few quest and unlocking a costume for collecting all of them.   You gain treat cards by defeating enemies and completing quest.

[h1]The Combat [/h1]

The combat in Costume Quest is rather unique, upon starting the battle your given one option to select basic attack [b](unless you have a battle card which gives you a secondary option like a stun)[/b]  after selecting that option you're taken into a quick time event.  If you succeed in the quicktime event your character does extra damage, if you fail, your character does quite a bit less damage.  During the enemy phase of combat, when an enemy attacks one of your characters, you're given another quick time event, if you are successful you defend some of the damage and minimize the damage you receive, if you fail the quick time event the enemy a significant amount of extra damage.

Special ability's   -  those special abilities each costume has I mentioned above are useful here, after three combat turns each of your character unlocks their costumes special ability, this can be anything from from protection, heals, massive damage to a single or all enemies.  It's a good idea to mix and match your party to ensure you have all your bases covered in terms of combat, defense and healing.  A good defense is a good offense makes sense in this case.  It's especially important to include some type of healing for your party, as no healing exist outside of special ability or battle cards.  

The combat sounds simplistic and it is, but the quick time events keep the gamer engaged and on their seat with each successive battle, letting your guard down can and probably will result in you suffering a defeat.

[h1] Pro's [/h1]
Good story,
interesting characters
unique combat system
very fun to play
easy to 100% if you're into achievements
controller support

[h1] Con's [/h1]
Can be a bit too easy with the right combination of costumes/battle cards
Slightly repetitive enemies
occasionally controls can glitch out


[h1] Recommendation [/h1]

I'd highly recommend this game, on paper it looks rather simplistic, it seems to have many strikes against it from a gamer's perspective prior to even installing it, but trust me on this one, once you start playing and get into the story you'll be thoroughly entertained as I was.  A fun game to play and enjoy, once you start to play you'll want to keep playing until you finish the the story.  It can be a bit difficult to get into, especially when you realize you'll be playing with children as characters, but that's part of the charm, a person of any age can kick back and enjoy the thrills and exciting of going trick or treating once again.. [b] (without having your neighbors call you a cheapskate bastard for trying to collect candy from them)[/b]  I'd really suggest taking the plunge, buying the game, collecting the candy and saving Halloween for children and adults all across the world..

Quick Summary: Costume Quest is a “children’s” RPG focused more on story than on graphics or complexity. The actual gameplay reminds me of a simplified Chrono Trigger or similar Japanese RPG where you travel the map with semi random encounters and fight by taking turns exchanging attacks with the enemy.

I called it a children’s RPG, by which I mean not only is the story about a group of kids (even the main bad guy is a child) but the story would be considered PG if it were a movie. You control a group of kids teamed up on Halloween to stop monsters from stealing all the candy, using the power of your Halloween costumes. In the main world you look like a bunch of kids in homemade costumes, but when you encounter enemies and enter battle, you become whatever you’re dressed as. For example some of the costumes are robot, jack o’ lantern, or unicorn. Outside of battle you’re free to change your team’s costumes to whatever you have unlocked, and some costumes have some sort of real world effect (for example the robot allows you to run fast).

When your team is in battle, the options are extremely limited. You can either run away, attack, or use a special move. The special move is unlocked every few combat rounds and usually it’s something like a big attack or a healing spell for your team. An added combat mechanic is the ability to boost your attack or weaken the enemy attack by doing an easy quicktime event. For example every time you attack you press the correct button in time and your attack does 10% more damage, or you press it at the right time during the enemy attack and only take 90% normal damage.

Pros:
+Decent cutesy, fun story for kids. Nothing a parent would have to worry about.
+Very simplified gameplay, with some element of skill in boosting attacks or finding hidden items in the world.
+The DLC Grubbins on Ice is included and adds a few hours more gameplay.

Cons:
-Kind of a childish game, but you knew what you were getting into.

Overall the game is a nice diversion that you can finish in a few days. I only played it at first because when Steam was releasing their trading cards, this was the one of the first games I owned with cards and I figured I’d give it a try while waiting for cards to drop. It was not disappointing.

So if you're dressed as the Statue of Liberty, you can use a healing spell to restore HP to the whole group, or you can hit the enemy with your torch to set them on fire.  If you are the robot, you can rocket-punch a single enemy or use your missiles to attack all the enemies.  And the other costumes have additional things going for them.  As you play more of the game, you will find parts of new costumes.  Only if you find all the parts can you make the costume.  

In addition to changing costumes, you can also buy badges that give additional abilities.  One lets you add a little poison to your attacks.  Another adds a bigger poison with splash damage to nearby enemies.  Another boosts your HP so you live longer.  Another boosts your damage, but only if you make a critical hit.  You make a critical hit by getting good timing when you push the button displayed on screen.  Critical hits are very easy, I think I only ever missed two.  The first was because I didn't know how to do it yet, the second was because I sneezed and it messed up my timing.

This game is not particularly difficult.  It is also not very big or long.  Still, it is fun for a little while.  It also has an expansion pack (standalone) where the kids visit the monster world at Christmas time and help the monsters overthrow a dictator.  New costumes are available in the expansion.  You can load your end-game save from the original game and start with the same characters, badges, and costumes when you boot up the expansion.

Bottom line:  it's cute and fun, but don't expect too much from this one.

As a fan of Double Fine's earlier efforts, especially Psychonauts, it's no surprise Costume Quest drew my attention with little effort. Given I'm also a fan of costuming and Halloween, this was pretty much an instant sell. Having fully completed the game, I can assure you it did not disappoint.

Right from the get-go, Costume Quest shows efforts to include every possible player, as you can choose to play as either the boy (Reynold) or girl (Wren) of a pair of twins. Soon after the twin you didn't select is kidnapped by monsters for dressing like a delicious-looking candy corn, you meet up with other trick-or-treaters your age that match your level of imagination and your desire to get your sibling back.

Costume Quest feels like an RPG stripped down to its essentials, with timing-centric, turn-based combat and set amounts of spawns in most areas. This, along with the enemies' leveling along with you, eliminates the need for experience grinding. Wiping out everything is still necessary for 100% completion and makes getting costume upgrades and some secrets easier, but you can get by if you stick to story-necessary encounters.

The game itself feels a bit small, area-wise, but there are plenty of tasks in each section to keep your party busy and searching for hidden items and secret costumes. A great balance is struck between backtracking through each section and forward progression, so it rarely, if ever, feels like a slog.

The variety of costumes is also nice, especially their in-combat forms. Due to the children's imaginations, whatever costume they're wearing transforms into a majestic, towering version of its mundane representation, all featuring beautiful animations and unique, often hilarious special attacks. As touched on before, combat is straightforward, with timed button presses coming into play on top of the base mechanics to lessen incoming damage and stack combos with your own attacks.

All in all, Costume Quest is relatively short, super sweet, and great for any time of year. Just remember that a couple of achievements (for the game and for the Grubbins On Ice DLC) are time-associated, so be ready to fire the game back up when more seasonably appropriate. You could just wiggle your PC clock a bit, but that'd be lame.

Not bad

Story
You are a kid that goes Trick and Treating with their sibling who is swiftly kidnapped by monsters. Now it is your job to go door to door trick or treating, complete quests, and fight monsters. It’s pretty much a standard RPG with a halloween theme painted on it. The story isn’t bad and it follows Double Fine’s formula well (kid looking game with often adult adventures that is eccentric). There are some dark elements to the game which come out really well and the whole game has a theme of child wonder to it. You fight as real transformers, unicorns, and vampires while facing daemons. It sounds like a kid fantasy. However, the story isn’t flushed out as Psychonauts for example and I don't really remember much

Gameplay
It’s a standard RPG (with a twist). The main point is to go around to all of the stores/houses and trick or treat. Different areas are blocked out until you can unlock certain areas. This is mostly done through monster fights. Overall, this system is nice as it moves the plot along via your actions but gets very repetitive near the end as you just end up going from monster fight to monster fight. 

Speaking of which, the monster battles are a bit simple. You can have up to 3 characters each of which has a regular move and a special ability with a long cool down. Additionally, you have different patches you can apply which are absolutely necessary to stand a chance. It took me a while to find a pair that worked for me but in the end, it was all just the same thing over and over until the end. Overall, I found the system a bit simple and I don’t play RPGs much

Performance:
With a 4790k, GTX 970, and 16GB of ram, it ran at either 30 or 60fps for me. It didn’t vary in between those two numbers but rather certain scenes and areas were stuck at 30. The game isn’t aiming to be realistic so the graphics are cartoony.

Overall, the game was OK. I’m reminded of South Park: The Stick of Truth a lot and honestly, I would recommend playing that over this game. It’s not bad but just kinda meh to above meh.

The game is beautiful for a halloween-themed game. Coffins are chests, you can trick-or-treat houses for candy or enemy encounters, battle stamps which improve your character in fights and several comedic speeches for all ages. I absolutely adore this game.

Every game (excluding racing games) contain bosses (I think). These bosses were rather time consuming but if you had the right costumes for your team, it would be a piece of cake. I did find one boss in the game rather annoying but dont want to spoil it. I would say something about the boss, but just wait till you fight her. 

There are costumes you find from side quests or just main quests. These costumes play a big part of the game not just because its the games title, but you actually get different move sets aswell. The costumes I found made the final boss a 1 try victory for me. The game can be a bit easy if you get guides on where the costumes are located and its pieces. 

There is another playable DLC you get automatically if you purchase this game on steam, called Grubbins on Ice. It's not extremely long, its about 1/3 of the games length. I did enjoy it though because it gave me three costumes, several battle stamps and a nice adventure. I would prefer playing this after the base game because everthing from your first save in Costume Quest, gets sent over into the DLC. It's pretty helpful. It is recommended to do that because enemies are about lvl 13 and your cap is lvl 10 (in the base game). 

This game is a master piece literally. I love it so much and for the price I got it for (99 cents in the 2015 holiday sale) it was worth it. If you see this game going for about $5 or less, purchase it immediately. THIS TITLE IS A MUST-BUY. 

I LOVE YOU DOUBLE FINE PRODUCTIONS!

19514975.review:
[b] [i] What better way to spend a few hours than pummeling monsters as a giant rainbow unicorn? [/i] [/b]

Costume Quest is a fun, youthful, and humorous adventure that utilizes overworld exploration, puzzle solving, and a simple turn-based combat system. I would recomend it to children, people looking for a not-scary halloween game, and anyone who would like to nostagically relearn some of the magic of halloween.

This game does a lot of things well and a few things not so well.

[h1] Good Stuff: [/h1]

[b] Concept [/b] - I love the sheer idea of this game. A group of kids must use their costumes that ACTUALLY TRANSFORM THE WEARERS to fight monsters, save a sibling, and collect tons of candy along the way. It sounds like all of my childhood halloween fantasies at once.

[b] Story [/b] - Less predicatable than one might image. It has just enough twists to keep it interesting, but manages to keep it simple enough for a younger person to enjoy it.

[b] Characters [/b] - Likeable child characters are comparable to black republicans nowadays: maybe there's one or two here and there, but overall they're pretty rare. The children in this game are highly likeable and funny, which is a metaphorical breath of fresh air.

[b] Humour [/b] - My inner 10 year old got a real kick out of this game. The jokes are silly and childish, but I'd be lying if I said I didn't laugh quite a bit during my playthrough. I wish more games could imbue such a good sense of humour into their games.

[h1] Stuff That Was Ok: [/h1]

[b] Music [/b] - It wasn't exactly a synphonic masterpiece, but it does add to the immersion. My only qualm is that the battle music can get a bit repettitive.

[b] World/Map [/b] - Again, it wasn't mind blowing or pioneering or anything like that. Each area is pretty different, which does well to break up any monotony. Some environmental objects (specifically, ramps) can feel really clunky, but all-in-all it doesn't affect the enjoyment of the game.

[h1] Stuff I Wish Was Different: [/h1]

[b] Character Progression [/b] - I believe that the Devs wanted to create a simple RPG that was less about combat and leveling up and more about the story. They absolutely succeeded, so props to them. I do wish that there would have been a slightly more in-depth character upgrade system, but that's just me.

[b] Combat [/b] - Like I said above, the game isn't really combat or skill focused. The combat is simple and easy to learn, which is good. The problem with simple combat is that it can get very, very repetitive. I was actually somewhat sad when the thought "ugh, do I really have to fight these guys?" came to mind, because to me it meant that the combat had gotten boring. It's worth noting that I was admittedly about 3/4 of the way through before that happened.

[b] Lighting [/b] - My last minor complaint is the lighting in the game. For the majority of the game, the Devs did a great job of keeping the overall lighting pretty low, but bright enough to see where you were going and to find the things you needed to find. However, the [spoiler] first part of the 2nd act and the upper two floors of the mall area [/spoiler] are just too dark. There is a brightness option in the menu, but amping up the brightness seems almost to be cheating, since part of the game's charm is the comic-spookiness of low lighting. That's really my only complaint on the world design.



[h1] Final Summation: [/h1] [b] I really did enjoy this game. It was a fun way to spend a few hours, and it made me think back to my childhood dreams about being the costume I wore on halloween. Would recommend. [/b]

Not much to say other than “This game is awesomely fun!”

If you love the classic turn based RPG's and comical adventures, then you will like this game. As the name implies, the game is about costumes. You and your sibbling start out Trick or Treating when these monsters kidnap one of you mistaking you for candy. You must go on a quest to recover your sibbling before the night is over. 

The game works on two levels. The first is the main view (or town) where you solve simple puzzles and go door to door Trick or Treating. When you meat a monster you go to the battle level.

In the town you are in a cheaply made costume that looks like a kid made it. The streets have other kids walking around in various costumes and adults that have quests that need completing in order to pass by. Once you have visited all the houses, you are allowed to go to the next part of town.

In the battle section, your characters transform into whatever costume you had on. Each costume has normal attacks, special attacks, stat benefits, and/or a special ability outside combat.

The graphics for this game are in no way realistic. It was designed to look cartoonish. Not saying that the graphics are bad. On the contrary, for the style they went with, they look awesome. The backgrounds are highly detailed, the characters look smooth, the costumes really look like they were pieced together with cardboard and various things around the house.

The combat is probably the only place I would have any complaints with. When you begin, you can only do a normal attack unless you have a “battle stamp” that allows a secondary attack. On your third turn you will be allowed a special move. You can use it then or save it for later. The problem is that you have to wait 3 turns to use it again. Additionally, when you go to do your normal attack you have to press the corect sequence or yo will do about 1/2 to 3/4 damage. This is also tru with defending. If you fail to hit the proper button on time you will receive full damage. “Battle Stamps” will help with the combat but are limited to 1 per character. This is all there is to the fights. Granted there is a bit of strategy involved with the combat, this is very limiting.    

All in all, this was a very fun game and the DLC was also fun. Neither are super long but are very fun to play...

18517168.review:
I don't know about other people, but I think Halloween got me more excited than any other holiday, even Christmas. There was something fun about "being" something else for a night. Also, the pails full of candy. Double Fine does a wonderful job portraying the things I loved about Halloween as a kid while also giving me things to appreciate as an adult.

The art direction is top notch. There is a very consistant design aesthetic that carries through the entire game, one that would look right at home as part of a Halloween cartoon special. The character design eschews realism for expressiveness - not quite to the completely distended extremes of Psychonauts, but still not aiming for "realism". The main characters are kind of chibi, which is great because it allows for a remarkable expressiveness. Par for the course in a Double Fine title, the dialogue (all written, no voice acting) is really sharp and loaded with humor both obvious and subtle. The background music tends to be fairly repetitive, but it's atmospheric and compliments the visual design. Shades of Danny Elfman, which is a *perfect* choice for Halloween.

The game itself is a turn-based RPG but with active, timing based offense and defense boosts. It's very similar to Super Mario RPG (which, if it didn't innovate that style definitely codified it) in how it plays out. Actually, of any game to compare the gameplay to, I'd compare it to Hothead's Penny Arcade Adventures. It's funny, Ron Gilbert came over from Hothead just a month before the game was released - he didn't actually have any direct impact on the game, but given Tim Schafer and Ron Gilbert's long-term association, I can't but help think he cribbed from his friend's design. Which is fine because it worked then and it worked in this game. Add in a dash of Earthbound, in being able to engage with enemies on screen before the turn-based battle begins, and you've got a tried-and-true formula.

The costume transformations are fun and the special powers associated with the costumes are anywhere from "useful" to "hilarious", in the case of the Lady Liberty costume. One thing the game could be dinged on is a lack of variance in combat. There's only one special power per costume, and a handful of optional "third powers" that can be added. In actual practice, a lot of combat could be completed by just attacking, waiting for the special attack to power up, unleash the attack and if anything is still standing repeat the process. The combat is thankfully fast-paced for a turned-based RPG, but it can get somewhat repetitive.

I could harp on a few other things. The game is short - even if you explore and find everything, expect 5-6 hours at most if you're able to win most battles (and you probably will). Of course, as an adult with a job, short isn't a crime for me, but those who hear RPG and expect 99 hours of playtime will be sorely disappointed. The story is simple, which fits a game about a bunch of kids on Halloween night turning into their costumes and saving their sibling and their candy stashes, but there could have been a little bit more meat on the story's bones. Characterization was strong and it goes a long way, but the world of Costume Quest is charming enough that I felt like I was missing something to not get more. The environmental "puzzles" are barely a challenge and the solutions are nearly flat out stated by some NPCs who might as well add "GET IT?" to their obvious, pun-based solutions. Then again, it's a great entry level title for children. For adults, you'll probably find the puzzles and their solutions too, too easy.

But those are quibbles. Costume Quest is one of the most charming games I've played. It's got a great atmosphere and  great idea for a game that ends before the shtick gets old. The game also, I might add, is fairly diverse in its characterization and does not limit costumes amongs the PCs by gender. Yes, Double Fine, I noticed, and it's an awesome thing to see game designers implement.

I definitely recommend this game to people tired of gray-and-gritty, guns-and-guts gaming. The game will make you smile. It's no challenge at all, if that's how you want to measure "worth" in a game, but the wit of the game and the clever concept will make the game worth the price of admission in my opinion. It's a perfect compliment to the season and if you have even the barest interest in RPGs - or have never played one before and want one to try that isn't going to overwhelm you with entirely new gaming concepts - you'll enjoy the game. And just like Halloween candy, don't rush the experience. Savor it instead of gobbling it all down at once. I get the temptation, but you'll just get a tummy ache if you do!

Usually when you think of a Halloween game, you think of a scary game, and those are all well and good; but what about a game that really brings the magic of Halloween itself? You know, costumes, trick or treating, having fun with your friends? 

Costume Quest somehow does it and does it very well. The first level already brims with nostalgia of days gone by (for me anyway) of walking the neighborhood at night and going door to door with a pale for the candy. 

You may wonder what the gameplay is like - well, first off the story is not serious, it's a light-hearted romp that'll make you smile for all ages. 

The overall story begins as your brother or sister (depending on who you choose to play as) gets kidnapped by strange monsters who love candy, and you are going to rescue them. 

The gameplay itself mostly is you going door to door in various places, and sometimes you get an adult with candy (which is like a currency in the game), or it could be a monster, which whom you have to fight.

The fighting is done like a turn-based RPG, and you can get little things to help you out, called Battle Stamps. Each stamp has a unique ability you can use, each of your character gets one stamp per person, but you can switch them out if you don't care for it.

There's no real dying in the game, you lose a battle, and you can just try again. 

The settings are really fun, like a neighborhood with various decorations, or a mall etc. The humor is really good, and adults and children will enjoy it, it's really a game for the family. Sadly, there's no co-op but it's fun on its own.

There's also the DLC "Grubbins on Ice" included which adds 1-2 hours more. The core game isn't TOO long even getting everything, maybe 4-5 hours? But it's a lot of fun, and if you want to feel that Halloween nostalgia, this is the perfect game for you! 

The sequel is also very good, and worth checking out if you like the first one.

Costume Quest with its add-on Grubbins on Ice is a nice Halloween-themed almost-RPG. It's, in one word, candy. I like candy.

I highly recommend using a controller with this game. Keyboard controls felt pretty odd.

Achievement Hint: [spoiler]The game doesn't know the date. It asks your machine for the date.[/spoiler]

+ Creepy Treats (collectibles) design
+ Non-irritating but forgettable music
+ Back To The Future discovery sound
+ Costumes with exploration effects in addition to battle effects
+ Costume battle action design
0 no map
0 Mostly inconsequential Battle Stamps (buffs)
0 Level caps
- Incorrect Battle Stamp descriptions
- Pretty linear
- Almost consistently no challenge
- No description on save slots when loading
- After the main game we see the credits headlined "Grubbins on Ice"

Technically the game is about quasi-isometric exploration with battle intermezzi.
The battles are similar to those associated with RPG-Maker games or for example Final Fantasy 7 but instead of action meters there is simply a battle order. Without fail, first your up to three character attack, then the up to three enemies - repeat until defeat.

Although this may sound dry, the game is surprisingly fun. I played the game for maybe 11 hours, got stuck twice for a total of about 90 Minutes (misunderstood game mechanics in the beginning + final boss in the add-on) and it was entertaining enough to feel like around 4 hours.
This is mostly due to a number of good design decision. For me, the game wasn't so much about the main storyline but more about your party of characters speaking with each other, other inhabitants of the area and enemies, and it was about the battles. For some reason those things made me think, I'd like to play this in a Spongebob Squarepants world, at one point.

In order of relevance the advancements in the game are: gaining companions, completing new costumes and getting Battle Stamps. Ultimately progress in the game requires the player to win fights (actually you go trick-or-treating but half the time that results in fights) but there are a number of obstacles that require you to explore beforehand.

*Companions*
Companions come with a new costume and provide an extra action per round in battle.

*Costumes*
You get costumes with characters or you are given a blueprint which sort of tells you, by way of a somewhat indiscriminate outline, which three components/materials you need to complete the costume. Components are unique and can be found in more or less hidden treasure chests, given to you by inhabitants of the world, and maybe, I don't quite remember, be part of battle spoils. Once a costume is complete, it can be assigned to any of your characters.
Half of the costumes come with an Exploration Ability, i.e. an ability that can and (with the exception of one  costume in the add-on) must be used in the exploration part of the game. The most important ability is the Boost that you get with your very first costume. The Boost allows your party to speed across the area and is essential to the pacing of the game. At one point or another, the player is likely to miss something plus there is a little back and forth in the game anyway. Without the Boost ability that could have easily turned into a chore - very good design decision.
All of the costumes but one have a Combat Ability, i.e. a special that needs two battle rounds to load and can be executed instead of a normal attack.
Apart from having an effect on game-play the costumes just look cool. Even if there wasn't an achievement connected to that I'd still recommend to take every costume into battle at least once. I simply like the progression of the costumes from the materials you have to collect over the (not really) crappy "not quite there" or "Dad did the best he could" design of the costume as the characters are wearing it in exploration mode to the awesome "this is how the kids see it" (or maybe "this is what adult think how the kids see it") design in battle, character design and attacks.

*Buffs*
Battle Stamps are buffs that can be assigned to your party's characters, one each. Buffs include boosts to health, defence, dodging, counter-attacks, the over-powerful stun and the underwhelming auto-revive - usually buffs are passive. I basically stuck to the same buffs throughout the game, occasionally upgrading when a better version of the buff turned up.
Unfortunately, some of the buffs have misleading descriptions, most irritatingly the auto-revive is supposed to revive a character after one round. While this is technically correct a more apt description would explain, the character is revived after two rounds (one round after one round, see?). I only ever tried the buff when I had trouble with the final boss in the add-on and having a character inactive for two rounds is just unacceptable in that fight.

*Collectibles*
The Creepy Treats are mostly just nice-to-have. You collect them mainly as battle spoils and sometimes trade them with inhabitants. I guess they are mostly original ideas, e.g. Licorice Cables, Chocolate Hamburgers, Coconuts & Bolts, Misfortune Cookies.

*Battles*
As said before, each round in battle has your character(s) act first, then the up to three enemies. Usually, rounds go on until one side is defeated. In theory, there is an option to run away but I haven't tried it yet.
Each round each character chooses one of standard attack, the costume's Combat Ability (if ready) or the Battle Stamp buff (if active). Standard attacks have QTEs connected to them. There is a number of different QTEs, i.e. hitting a specific, dynamic button in time, hitting a specific, dynamic button on time, moving the left analogue stick around, and repeatedly pressing a specific, dynamic button. The type of QTE is dependent on the costume. If you pass the QTE, the character deals 50% more damage.
Combat Abilities need two rounds to load so they can be used every third round. They are usually a tactical option and it's not always useful to use them right away. For some reason, attack buffs do not affect Combat Abilities. This may even make the standard attack a preferable option overall.
Some Battle Stamp active buffs can be executed instead of a standard attack. Of those the most powerful are likely the different stun abilities which can take a single enemy out of the fight for up to two rounds. Except for bosses, the later game can be played without ever getting hit by an enemy. This is very powerful since even a "failed" enemy attack can take as much as 25% of a characters live away.
Some Combat Abilities can prevent almost all damage to characters.
Enemies mostly do standard attacks which lead to a defensive QTE which, on success, prevents half of the damage to the character. Magically inclined enemies can heal, buff attack or defence of one of the enemies.
Battles are pretty short and easy but fun, largely because of the costumes. 

*Game Experience*
A few more words on the game. One of the rather negative aspects about the game is its linearity. Bring me this and that or you cannot go on, fight those guys or you cannot go on, complete a costume or you cannot go on. But this is well compensated by the entertainment factor.
Even though of limited use, I'd have liked a map to come with each area. This was sort of addressed in the add-on where you gain the ability to zoom out a bit with a costume.
The game was a bit on the easy side.
When loading/continuing a previous savestate the game doesn't tell you anything about the progress made. The game simply lists "Slot 1", "Slot 2" and "Slot 3". There isn't even an indication whether the slot actually contains any saved progress. This is a minor ugliness.

I had a lot of fun with Costume Quest and Grubbins on Ice and highly recommend the game. I'm looking forward to playing the sequel.

This is essentially a casual RPG for kids, but I'm reviewing it anyway as an adult.

Costume Quest is a very short turn-based RPG, but the highlight of its features are what it doesn't have. It's devoid of pretty much any interesting game system. The slim turn-based combat system present is similar to the Final Fantasy games, but you'll get more depth out of Final Fantasy games or 99% of their copycats. All of the combat uses Quick Time Events as well, which gets old after the second or third combat encounter. Game balance is simple and a little skewed. The game can be difficult (but hardly) when you only have two party members, and its trivially easy once you have three.

The overworld is linear. There's a tiny bit of exploration to be had, but not much. There are roughly four quests in the entire game, each repeated several times for each phase of the game: find a card off a monster (combat encounters), bob for apples (simple mini-game), trick or treat houses (random combat encounters), and find six hiding kids (semi-hidden on overworld).

The game crashed a few times, and since there is no manual save feature at any time, I lost 15-20 minutes of progress each time. The game plays the same every time.

There are costumes to get, which are your battle suits or "classes". Variation here is only relevant in the costume's "special ability" but the game is so easy that once you have three party members, battle strategy matters little.

Graphics meh, sound meh, witty dialogue is OK but not astounding. No voice acting.

I don't recommend this game. You can find much better games in all of its genres for cheaper.  If you insist on wanting it, it's worth $2-3 on a sale perhaps. My playtime says 16 hours but that included a long idling session by accident. It's a 5-7 hour game. 

I'm surprised this game has a sequel. It's popularity seems dependent on the Double Fine brand, which hasn't been the same for me since Spacebase DF and the Broken Age Kickstarter mishandlings.

This game is very simple, and in some ways feels like a cheaper, off-brand version of a bigger JRPG, namely one of the Persona series, given that you fight with the powers of a swappable costume.

But it's got a lot of charm, delightfully cohesive theming, good writing that allows the kids to be kids, and sprawling level design with slightly retro area access puzzles that fit into the Hallowe'en theme very well.

There are turn-based battles with quick time events to maximize your damage and reduce the enemies'. They aren't always easy. There is also a two layered strategic system of costume specific special abilities and 'battle stamp' special abilities that can be used with any costume. There are quite a lot of ways to build effective combinations, and in some difficult battles, you will have to adapt your strategy to the circumstances to succeed.

Downsides? Well, the camera angle is fixed and with levels so sprawling and complex, it can be easy to miss things hidden behind the foreground that are mandatory for story progression and to have to search for them.
Some of the puzzle solving is quite silly, and the player characters' unprompted hints to solve them can be annoying as often as they are helpful.
If a baddie wandering on the overworld map initiates combat with you and you lose, you get spat back out in exactly the same place, and the baddie will immediately initiate combat again, giving you no time to switch up your strategy before being launched into exactly the same battle; that can be a bit frustrating.
And finally, the lack of complexity can mean that the simple mechanics get a little bit dull even over the short playtime.

So its JRPG lite, but I recommend it for the charm alone. This game has actually made me question my disillusionment with the corporatization of Hallowe'en by showing me the cuter costumes and candy in a more wholesome and fun light. If you have kids, invite them to play it too. It seems like a very child-friendly game.

[h1]AT A GLANCE[/h1]
(Full review follows below)

[list]
[*] [b]Game Name:[/b] Costume Quest
[*] [b]Original Release:[/b] 2011
[*] [b]Genre Tags:[/b] RPG; Casual; Adventure; Lighthearted   
[*] [b]My Overall Grade:[/b] A-
[*] [b]Estimated Playtime (Campaign):[/b] 5-10 hours
[*] [b]Multiplayer Aspect:[/b] None
[*] [b]Recommended To:[/b] Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Casual gamers
[/list]

[h1]REVIEW[/h1]
[b]Costume Quest[/b] has a lot of good things going on for it.  The game takes you on a journey of the imagination as some children’s quest for candy on one Halloween night quickly turns into something much more.  Ultimately, this game is just very well done and has a “soul” that should easily appeal to a vast audience.

The level design is charming and exploring the maps is fun.  The whole concept of “trick-or-treating” being a fundamental part of the gameplay is brilliantly done.  The story is basically one giant trope, but the way it is told is delightful.  The characters are likeable and the humor is clean but entertaining.  Even the style in which you warp into old-school, turn-based battles is executed well and synergizes perfectly with the atmosphere of the game.  This game is a quintessential example of how several good things can work together to create something great.    

As I alluded to, one of the most charming aspects of [b]Costume Quest[/b] is the way “trick-or-treating” in the game world is a central part of progressing the game.  You knock on doors and are either given candy (treat) or have to fight a battle (trick).  This leads to another splendidly charming feature of the game, which I also alluded to earlier: the battle warp-ins.  Depending on what costumes your characters are wearing, they change from little kids into various gallant warriors with nothing but the power of their imagination.  From there, the battles play out in the old-school, turn-based RPG style that was prevalent in the 90s.

Aside from that, you may also want to explore the levels, find secret areas, meet characters, and do side-quests and mini-games to gather more candy and collect the trading cards.  There is plenty to do!

[b]Costume Quest[/b] is a charming little game that makes for quite an enjoyable experience.  As I said, I feel it can appeal to a wide audience.  I would posit: if it sounds like the [i]type[/i] of game you [i]may[/i] enjoy, it will probably be a [i]specific[/i] game you [i]do[/i] enjoy… if you decide to get it.

Costume Quest is a simple but well put together party based RPG game. You play the role of a child who is obsessed with halloween, and spends the night going around the neighborhood trick or treating to get his candy. At the beginning of the game, your twin sister is kidnapped and you embark on your journey to rescue her. Along the way you make friends with other trick or treaters who join your party. 

While you are walking around the world, you are able to pick up extra candy, talk to the residents of the town and start battles with the bad guys. The combat system in Costume Quest is turn based, each of your characters will have their own costume which all have different powers. The combat is also primarily quick time events, which is normally not something I am a fan of, but it works quite well here. 

The graphics are nothing special, but they do look pleasing and the cartoon style is something which fits the story and setting nicely. Sadly the audio in Costume Quest lets it down, there isn't any voice acting, and very little sound effects when you are walking around the world.

The game is set across four different levels, each of them has their own theme and style, with lots of different items and hidden locations to find in each of the levels, they feel plumped out and interesting to explore. I didn't find there to be any difficulty, you can complete the game without being beaten once, so maybe a New Game+ mode would of fixed that. I'm not sure why Steam has counted me having sixteen hours, as the game took me about five hours to complete along with the majority of all the side missions and achievements. 

I only really ran into one technical issue, and that was frame rate, the Steam in game counter shows it running at 30 fps while walking around the world, while in the combat phases, this jumps up to 60 fps. I noticed some screen tearing with v-sync off, but this also may be an issue with my rig (I don't think it is considering the specs I run), but it was nothing major. 

I can recommend Costume Quest, because I had a really good time playing, and it has a different take on the party based games, and for the full price of £6,99, you can't go wrong with the amount of content that is included.
